reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor those of you who stared in awe at the space battles in the remake of Battlestar Galactica or wanted a more up close and personal take on the fleet actions in Homeworld 2, Fractured Space is going to make you happy in your pants.  Whether you're leading the charge in a Flagship, rushing an open sector in a Frigate or closing in to finish off a crippled foe in a Hunter, Fractured Space is big ships, big guns, big fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATE 29.05.2016

Something important: I am a supporter of this game and I need to say that who ever is reading the reviews on this game should look at the playtime of the person who wrote that. You need to play at LEAST ten matches (~4-5 h playtime) to actually get into the whole system. Many of the negative reviews are from players that have no clue how ANYTHING works and start to complain about it here. I know now after a couple of weeks the reviews I am talking about have more playtime than at the point when they wrote it but they never changed or updated the review to say whether it's better now or not.

Review:

Okay, I played this game now since the first free weekend back in April 2015 and two weeks ago I reached my 1000th hour of playtime in Fractured Space. Updates are coming frequently with a lot of content and new stuff which is tested by the community. In the last weeks after ECG had released their biggest patch ever for this game a lot of people came to this site to write a negative review and whine about stuff that is completeley new without having it tested for about a week. This stuff is now tested and it works. Not perfect but way better than a week after the patch.

AFTER THE UPDATE

We got a new Crew System which makes it harder to get the crewmembers (they give you some extra % on your ship like damage, damage reduction, cooldown on abilities, etc.). I am not a fan of this system but I waited a bit for ECG to listen to the community and so they did. They are still changing the system to make it less and less bad. And so they did. I personally think they should still increase the chance of getting a crewtemplate which is needed to unlock the crews. You get them after  2 (Bronze Drop),4 (Silver Drop) and 6 (Gold Drop - highes chance of course) games.

ENGINE AND GRAPHICS

As the game is running on Unreal Engine 4 the graphics just look amazing in it. Unfortunately the last big patch killed the performance for a lot of players but that happened after almost every content patch. ECG is doing their best to get the performance up again so that players with less powerfull computers can still play it. They anounced that a performance patch will come in the next weeks probably with the next content update. The details of the ship are just astonishing. They put so much work into the look of the ships that I actually dont want to fight with it but look at it for hours. Same for a lot of the animations especially the different Jump Drive animations. When it comes to sound the game gets a big plus from me too but some ships sounds are not powerfull enough even though they deal a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of damage when played right (i.e. the Gladiator: sounds got already improved but still sound like that it's shooting balls instead of bullets as big as my house).
Something I miss are the small animations on ships like opening some claps when missiles are fired. often they are launched out of the nowhere (i.e. Colossus or Destroyer).

GRINDING

Something actually no one likes to hear but even Fractured Space has it. In January 2016 a big wipe deleted all the progress to start the actuall grinding of the game. Before that the ships where easy to unlock so everyone could test them. Now they cost ten times the amount they did before. A normal player needs about 600 matches to unlock everything (loadouts included). This game is NOT Pay2Win as you can't buy EXP which is needed to unlock the ships. However you can buy Platinum which is the premium currency in FS and then buy the ships with it. But if you decide to do it like that you would be poor really soon as Platinum is really expensive and the ships cost a lot of it (i.e. 1k Plat = 5€, highest ships cost 4470 Plat where you would need to pay 25€). So if you are not rich just don't bother to get the normal ships with Plat.

SHIPS

The heart of the game. There are three different manufacturers: USR - United Space Research (could NASA from the looks), Zarek (Industrial) (are probably the russians) and TDS - Titan Defense Research (China...).
There are three different classes: Support, Defense and Attack. Every ship has another class ship describes the size and mass of it which are Smallcraft, Mediumcraft and Heavycraft.
All manufacturers have at least one type of each shipclass but play most of the time completely different. Then there is another class which tells you the needed skill to play the ship correctly (Tier 1 to 7). Of course for Tier 7 you need a lot of skill but they are NOT automatically better even though they are at the end of the techtree. As the devs said: All ships are balanced to play against each other. As you move up the Techtree
date:
the ships require more knowledge of the game to play."

GAMEPLAY

The gameplay itself is just awesome. Atleast if you are willing to have fun. Like in any other multiplayer game you get into games that are just frustrating and have zero fun. I see a lot of highly skilled players from different clans that are taking things too serious like they always play in a tournament. Fun ship combinations are rarely seen and when we meet them they always go with tryhard combinations so they just win this game without big effort. Fun combinations are rare in their team. The fights between two ships or more are simply awesome. A lot of players compare this game to Dreadnought where I have to say that Fractured Space is the more tactical variant and Dreadnought is better for casual players. To be honest you won't see a lot of tactics in the random matches mostly because of the lack of communication with the random players that get into your team and the big difference in skill. Playing in tournaments is the real thing. It's nothing like the random matches. You can truely feel the skill in the teams and how every single step is well thought to win the matches. If you want to see some tournament matches I recommend you to go to the forums and search for the "80k Tournament" and the "3vs3 Tournament" threads. Somewhere in there are streams of the tournaments where highly skilled players compete.

CONCLUSION

I end my review here by saying that you if you want to play this game you should go to the forums and search for some players to play with. Playing it alone is way less fun and way more difficult to get into the game. Don't hesitate to ask any players for advice if you think you could need some. There will always be some players that don't understand that others players might not be as good as they are but the majority of the playerbase is there to help you."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dota in SPACE*ominous voice*

Fractured space is a 5 vs. 5 team battle on areas of space that has been divided in various sectors. All sectors have control points you need to capture in order to advance and eventually make your way to enemy base. During combat you can freely fly in the battlefield, warp into sectors where the combat is currently going on and warp back to base to regroup or to run away with your nearly destroyed ship for repairs.

There's currently 15 different ship types in game, 3 of them unlocked right at the start. Ship types fit for many roles: long range, hard hitting sniper boat, heavily armored flagship for more close range combat, sneaky & stealthy assassin ship, fast moving frigate etc. As the game is currently in it's early stages, it understandably might have some balance issues between various ship designs - though I personally feel like every ship has their own use and an organized group will easily take down those solo snipers or assassins who think they can/should be able to kill everything themselves.

PROs:
Awesome ship design
Well made level
Graphics, sfx

CONs
1(one) level
Very low playerbase (seen max of 54)
Level Matching system(isn't one)
No real training/tutorials

For an EARLY ACCESS game, its good, Its not super great, but its really entertaining. Graphics are great, has a solid gameplay. People here are giving it negative reviews because they want a finished product but its no where near that stage yet. The game is great at its current stage and it can only get better from here. I'd definitely recommend this game for anyone who loves space sci-fi.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am the man with no name. Zapp Brannigan, at your service.

Here to tell you about Fractured Space, a game of capital ship combat. The game has beautiful ships, alright. Shapely, seductive… I’m going to fly their brains out. And although these ships are massive, they can be very maneuverable, so when you feel the Captain’s Itch you’re free to plot a course with some chest hair. Try using the asteroids for cover, by jack-knifing from one to the next at breakneck speed; you might just get some kind of gravity boost, or something.

The basics are easy to learn and you’ll be competent after a few games, and that’s coming from a man with a very sexy learning disability. The key to victory is the element of surprise. Backcap Surprise! And if your team takes Gamma, the rest of the dominos will fall like a house of cards. Checkmate.

After a long match, pulling off the win can be very satisfying… Kif, show them the medal I won.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Like any savvy consumer, I was put off by the 'Mostly Positive' rating this game has. But I saw multiple reviews saying those were from a previous generation of the game, and sure enough, all negative reviews stop around 10 months ago. Since then apparently there have been major updates and improvements, and you can check the updates, the Devs are still very active. That said, this may be an early access game, but it doesn't much feel like it. There are at least 2 or 3 dozen ships to choose from, and the games runs at a minimum of 60 fps for me, more often at around 70 or 80.

If you want a legitimate, space battlecruiser fighting game, give it a shot. After just 3 days I have completely fallen in love with this game, and there is enough depth and variation between each game that I don't see it getting old any time soon. If you like LoL, Smite, or any other Mobas (I don't really care for them, but I love this game), then bite the bullet and give it a try. But make sure to do the tutorials.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The devs admitted they made a mistake. That's huge.

This is a solid game at it's core. The last major patch added a crew collection system which was grindy and unsatifying. The community voiced it's opinion, and the devs saw that and responded. They apologized and are working to make reparations towards the players. Never before have I seen something of this caliber from game devs. Just because of this, I had to come write this review. Seriously, don't let the negative reviews scare you off if you are interested in playing the game. After all, it's free now, so it can't hurt to try.

I had avoided MOBA games like a plauge until I saw this one and was immediately interested. It has yet to dissapoint me. Sure, there are bugs, bad games, and frustrating matches, but I find that the gameplay and strategy aspects of the game more than make up for the low points. I am excited to see where this game goes as it continues in development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, it got a long way to go but from what i played it has ALOT of potential

First off, this IS NOT a space sim, don't come in thinking its Elite dangerous or the X Series, its not.

Rather what we do have is a very interesting twist on the MOBA genre.

Lanes are replaced with sectors of space, classes with different ship types and towers with space stations.

You capture resources bases in sectors of space for resources, that are spent on upgrades to level your ship in game. These are all very basic and I will assume what you spend will be expanded in the future, like upgrading just your engines  or buying stronger lasers etc. Right now thats all stat based.

Loadouts are very basic at the moment with only a few options for weapons and abilites.

There are 6 ships out as of now, but all have a unique playstyle and can counter each other, for example assassins have a inital advantage vs flagships due to there long range weapons, but up close a flagship will be able to do much more damage.

The performance sadly is were this game falls short, I have a GTX 760 and 8GB of ram and im struggling, but im sure this will be patched out in time.


TL;DR Very interesting MOBA style space game, wait for more patches before you buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Fractured Space on and off for the past year and always enjoyed but only after the recent Free-to-Play Update I got really into it.

They filled an empty niche, I've always wanted to play a Space combat game that doesn't require time-consuming intricacies (Example Eve) and they gave me just that. I like that the keyboard commands are not overwhelming (tiny hands!) which allows me to reroute all concentration into the battle itself. Oh and nearly forgot! I love the fact that each ship has its own role/personality!

The game aesthetic has improved a lot in the space of a year (Video -not mine- for comparison: https://youtu.be/zQF9q0I-exU ) and I know it will just get better.
Also, its amazing the level of detail given to the ships, even with the tools they have available, it requires a lot of patience/commitment.

Not very often I support an Early Access game because its like gambling but I don't have any disappointments over Fractured Space, was worth the risk and money well spent.

I'm looking forward to the future.

Best wishes,

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game's graphics 'looks' gorgeous, with it's high detailed mother ships which you can control, and satisfying weapon effects, and good controls. The movement is slow since they're big mother ships, but some (maybe it's just one) ships you can utilize to blink/jump short distances, which aside from looking cool, adds a good advantage to deal more damage if done correctly.

So the game at the moment (20/11/2014) has six ships and a conquest mode, pick your ship, it's crew, and go own your battle, a 5 vs 5 conquest match, with 7 major points, and 6 mini points to conquer. There isn't much else to say at the moment with the game being in alpha and all, with it comes bugs and little content, but overall I'm seeing this game hitting a good spot with it's nice price of 10 dollars, I think it's worth it, don't know if the price will go up but if you want an awesome experience I (hopefully) suspect that'll come around late beta stage, then give it a wait, but if you don't mind what you get now, then go ahead and get it.

What the game needs now is a good tutorial (also don't expect anything aside from 5 players, with their respective mother ships, against other 5 players of the same), more optimization, polish, and content. Also, this game would sell like hot cakes if there's coop, would love to have a 'assault stations' kind of coop.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=909Z5m1_GtE&feature=youtu.be

All in all I had a fun time playing it, and will play more, and for the asking price for what you get now and later on, it's a nice deal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like:
- Giant captial ship combat?
- Super pretty explosions?
- Super super pretty ship skins?
- And seriously tactical combat?

Then you'll probably like Fractured Space! It's a Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA) wherein two teams of 5 ships each compete for resources, and attempt to capture each other's home base. A lot of things explode, and it looks gorgeous.

Be warned, the current learning curve is pretty steep. There is a tutorial in the game, but it doesn't conver the sheer chaos that can ensure in an actual match. I STRONGLY recommend you check out some guides here on Steam and on Youtube. There are some very good Youtubers out there that break down an entire match step by step.

Please keep in mind that this game is still a work in progress. Things will change; sometimes it feels like a step backwards, but invariably the product has increased in quality. Especially the explosions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fractured space has been a very enjoyable game so far.

The game is still in alpha, and under constant development. In the last couple of months the developers have released an additional 5 ships, all with unique abilities and gameplay styles. Expanding on an already impressive collection of ships.

With over 20 ships you can choose a gameplay style to suit your character, mood, and opposing team, for example:

Play as a sniper, with a long range gun, picking off enemies half way across the map, while scared someone is going to jump on you from behind.
Play as a corvette, a ship with the ability to heal allies, and act as a floating shield.  What it lacks in damage output, it makes up in team cooperation and tactics.
Play as an infiltrator, the ability to fly across the map invisible, plant multiple explosive drones onto the hull of your enemy, before triggering a massive explosion.
Play as a hunter, a nimble ship with the ability to detect invisible enemies, the ability to teleport across distances to capture objectives, and employ evasive tactics to win dog fights.
Play as a reaper, an attack craft with the unique combination of weapons that allow you to damage armour, and deal heavy damage.  Limited angle of fire, but equipped with a short term shield which can assist when flanked.
Play as a brawler, a close range attack craft that can deal impressive damage when up close, and the ability to 'harpoon' enemies and reel them in close.
Play as a raven, a small ship with an impressive attack beam, which can only be fired after stealing energy from other ships.
If they don't sound like fun, then you can play as some of the more traditional ships like the flagship, destroyer, carrier, or leviathan, variations on the battle cruiser class ship, each with its own pros and cons.

The gameplay is heavily team and objective based. While a lot of games are played just using the in game communication, the real fun starts once you communicate with your team mates using voice. While the game lacks a voice system at the moment, the developers provide a teamspeak server, and a number of clans run their own.

That said, there are a number of issues with the game. Since the developers are constantly adding new features, and ships, the game is a constant state of needing rebalancing. While this is an ongoing process, there are some weeks where you find some ships are over powered, or your favourite strategy has become unviable. In the past few months, we have seen the carrier ship flop between being overpowered, and underpowered as the dev's fail to get the balance just right. This is more than acceptable throughout the alpha and beta stages of any game. Some of the other bugs that have shown up throughout the alpha have been worse, but as it stands, the game is massively playable, and I've put in a large number of hours, trying out new strategies and the gameplay mutates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
Overall Rating: 4/10
Gameplay Rating: 6/10 - simple, fun gameplay; no real explanation for essential aspects of the game
Accessibility Rating: 2/10 - no captions/subtitles

NotesOverall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and accessibility (how the game includes deaf/hoh gamers).  If you disagree with my take on the game or if something is factually incorrect, please leave a comment below!

General GameplayThis game is in ALPHA build, early access.  This review covers the game as it was on April 17, 2015 and includes feedback from developers regarding a temporary fix for rebinding keys for gameplay.  I FULLY suspect this rating will improve drastically over time.

So far, this appears to be a Control Points type game where you and your team of 4 other players try to capture stations in different quadrants to gain resources for ship upgrades that ultimately help you capture the enemy station.  Both teams fight for control of these stations and team members must work together to simultaneously capture points for your team and prevent the opponent from capturing for theirs.

Some Alpha stage problems do exist.
- First, it is difficult to get into a server - I often experience a failed join with no explanation as to why that is.
- Second, the basics of the game are in place, such as an initial set of ships and crew, but more are to be added, and there are some aspects of crew arrangement that seem to be placeholders for future functionality only.
- Third, as it is now, I have not seen any real tutorial for out-of-play experience (such as crew, ship selection and upgrading, and tech tree) to explain the details of what is what.
- Finally, the control schema for the game is only accessible outside of gameplay via the Hub interface rather than through game options.

On the plus side, the gameplay itself is fluid when you get into it and the currently available game mode is relatively easy to grasp without a steep learning curve.  Further, there is currently a rudimentary technology tree that offers different ships (and different styles of gameplay) based on an in-game credit system that currently requires no micro payments.

In its early stages, players seem to still be developing tactics for successful team play and I can see this game improving into something both challenging and fun to play with friends over time.

General Accessibility
Accessibility Options
+ You CAN edit options before playing the game.
+ HOH gamers CAN adjust audio controls separately for master volume, music, effects, and voice.

+/- Players with mobility issues can NOT currently rebind keys from inside the game, but the developers will add this feature soon.  For now, check out this guide if you are comfortable editing game files.

- Subtitles DO NOT exist for this game.


Subtitles & Captions
Captions/Subtitles DO NOT exist for this game yet.  It is playable without captions, but information may be missing.

Further, the instructional video on the Hub screen (when you first open game) is sourced from YouTube and the developers did not caption the video.  Deaf/HOH gamers must rely on Auto-captions for this video.

Chatting/Communicating
+ Gamers can communicate in game (both Team and All chat) with an easy-to-read chat system.


---
Visit Games Reviews for the Deaf/HoHhttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/gamereviewsforthedeaf

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To boot, it's some weird spaceship MOBA with a few elements from FPS games. (Aiming, leading targets, beautiful explosions and sassy crews.) The fact that I feed off space sims and worship the Homeworld series probably biases me a bit, but oh well. Here we go.

I'd have to say it's pretty fun, surprisingly. But there's a few points to keep in mind, so take my opinion with a grain of salt.

We can start with visuals. It's not bad in the looks department, but you don't have a huge selection for what you want on or off. (I'd love to turn off blur, but alas..) The only thing I find overwhelmingly cheesy is the Reaper's side-shield aesthetic. The maps are pretty simplistic, the bases even painfully moreso- It's upsetting seeing such pretty ships fly past such ugly stations.

Another pain is the camera positioning. Some may like it, some may not, I personally find it workable but a little bit chaotic- It can toy with your situational awareness and clips with nearby objects on occassion, and the secondary view with zoom is fixated on a sphere outside of the ship, so using it up close isn't ideal. You do get to look at that awfully pretty ship from third person, though. Even if it takes up more of your screen than is ideal.

What makes up for this is the gameplay. No fight is the same, and they range from slow to fast and in-your-face. It's incredibly unique that it nearly makes up for there only being one map. Forgive me if I sound a little passionate- I really enjoy the combat in this game.

Gameplay is really straightforwards- Five ships head against eachother for resources to improve their ships (Done automatically at the larger bases & home) and ultimately to capture the enemy base to secure victory. You've got five zones, pushing up through the outer two and hitting the middle when 'gas' pops up. (Capture the point to gain a boost to your firing, not always worth it mind you)

Because of how that works, kills aren't overly important until later in the game when respawning has increased from ~10 seconds to ~50+. You'll still want them though, since you get bonus XP/Credits for them, but your team can win a game with a nasty negative team K/D ratio.

Advancement is simple. You earn manufacturer points + credits from playing, and spend them to unlock + purchase ships or upgrades. (There aren't a lot of them yet.) In four rounds playing a certain manufacturer's ship, you should have enough to buy another ship.

Their to-do list looks pretty honest and leaves me hopeful that they'll stay true to their development. FOV sliders, new ships, a friends list, yes please and all in planned development. (Ideally.)

My recommendations are as follows..
Read the ship descriptions. They aren't lying when they point out a weakness/strength, and make sure you learn the ranges of your abilities. Each ship has their strengths and weaknesses against other ships and you'll learn these by playing them, so plan accordingly at the start of the match @ ship selection. Calling things OP is silly- Nothing is gamebreaking. Nothing.

Coordinate with your team! There's a voice chat and there's a chat box. Communication is vital. Please please please.

DO NOT TRASH TALK. You rarely pick your team and you could get teamed with someone who you were so rudely insulting that last match. Don't embarrass yourself, don't be that person. Play clean and get along with your team & enemies. Grudges are dumb on this.

Watch your important UI elements. Map awareness is extremely important, the game is surprisingly fast paced at times.

Friends are food. You might play with them or against them at the mercy of team balancing and other players, but it's nice to hear them curse when you blow them up. I suggest playing with them on voips for this.

And as always, keep in mind that this game is in alpha and there will always be room for improvement! Changes are (almost) always bound to come!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Solid gameplay so far. like the controls and handling of ships. pretty fun from what little ive already played. will try to add more to this as time goes on.

Game has more of a tactical element than it appears at first. all the ships have weaknesses and strengths to them. Used in a team effort with flanking manuveurs and jumping in at the right times and order could turn the tide of a battle quickly.   I beleive it is worth playing and learning all these elements to really get the most out of the game.   A lot of people seem to be giving it a quick 10 minute play and passing judgement....which just isnt possible.

This isnt a frantic speedy dogfighting game....this is a space battle with HUGE ships and epic scale. You are not going to have fast moving dodge and actiony stuff going on. the ships feel slow and lumbering.....but they are probably moving at extremely fast speeds and covering distances very quickly....but you cannot tell this without some sense of scale.  just imagine how large the ship you are controlling really is and look at how far you have to go to reach your destination and then see how long it takes. it feels like a long time but if you use some thought and logic its actually pretty quick when you consider the largest ship is like as big as the empire state building or larger and you just moved it a few miles in 10 seconds.....      ive seen some reviews say its slow and cumbersome and laggy...i dont think these people understand the scale and scope of what they are even looking at lol

As far as game performance goes i havent had any of the issues ive seen others mention. the menus work fine for me and the game stays at 60FPS average and drops to the 40s rarely when crazy stuff is happening but it doesnt feel like its hoppy i just saw it drop on the fps counter so it wasnt a problem for me.  I have the game maxed out with high settings at 1080p res on a lcd projector set to 140 inch screen size and a 7.1 speaker system. i have a secondary monitor on the side.
No performance issues for me.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMy thoughts on this game so far. It is a fun game to play when you can find a server with other players. Nothing feels quite like seeing a enemy use his missile barrage and than blinking to him and unleashing a full broadside of rockets in his face as his wasted missiles fly out into space. What they have in game now is fun all in itself and I for one am looking forward to the future updates. I have been wnating a game where can fight in capital ships for a long time now. The little details that they have in here is awesome too. When your ship is moving up or strafing left or right little thrusters along the hull can be seen firing. I like the ships style as well. The ships are something that looks like it belongs a hundred years in our future and not like slabs of metal that can shoot from wherever. Your turrets are mounted and can be seen turning and take time to rotate around. A match that I recently played I was flying the Assassin ship, which I believe is a cruiser or a destroyer class vessel. This thing is quite fast and hits pretty hard. Strafing runs are nice in this vessel. I could zoom by enemy capitals faster than thier turrents could track. To the dev's if you see this. reviewText:
Early Access Review

PROs :

* looks pretty good

* interesting game-mechanic in which you can teleport whenever you like

* finally some space-ships which dont explode after 0.001 seconds in battle

* the developers seem to target a strict role for your chosen ship - which is always good because                         hundreds and hundreds of  similar ships would only clutter the screen and reduce fun; nevertheless im hoping they will at least double (or triple) the amount of ships, that'd be awesome

* not really fast-paced, the typical, spasmic movement of your arm in hectic battles wont be needed here - THATS what MOBAs really need. Although a battle can end quite fast there is an overall relaxation in everything you do, yet it stays competitive and is fun


CONs:
* inexistent performance -- literally : if you dont own two processors with 8 cores each and at least two fast GPUs your game will stutter unbelievably; we're talking 2-3fps during combat here and its like that for most people ... its alpha, obviously but this NEEDS to get adressed sometime

* the game still is missing quite some content - its obviously a very early alpha so dont expect a full game

* they actually plan to release the game in 2015 .... um ... if this is gonna happen the game will be totally incomplete - lets all hope they change their mind

UPDATE :

PROs:
* performance problems are now somewhat resolved - i happen to have an octacore-CPU BUT i remember the game running much more smooth before i upgraded

* a few new ships have arrived - yet most of them still have no upgrades -- big room for improvement

CONS:
* Now that the performance got fixed the netcode appears to be sub-optimal, it will lag very often, depending on the server you are currently playing on - thats the next big thing they need to fix


UPDATE :

PROs: lags are not quite resolved but its much better now - one does not even need VPN anymore!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally an interesting spaceship-themed multiplayer combat!

Fractured space is a 5 vs. 5 team battle on areas of space that has been divided in various sectors. All sectors have control points you need to capture in order to advance and eventually make your way to enemy base. During combat you can freely fly in the battlefield, warp into sectors where the combat is currently going on and warp back to base to regroup or to run away with your nearly destroyed ship for repairs.

There's currently 15 different ship types in game, 6 of them unlocked right at the start. Ship types fit for many roles: long range, hard hitting sniper boat, heavily armored flagship for more close range combat, sneaky & stealthy assassin ship, fast moving frigate etc. As the game is currently in it's early stages, it understandably might have some balance issues between various ship designs - though I personally feel like every ship has their own use and an organized group will easily take down those solo snipers or assassins who think they can/should be able to kill everything themselves.

All ships have 6 different skills at the start, some more offensive, some more defensive. As you play and get more experience, you can unlock more skills and customize your ship's loadout. There's currently 2 different crews to choose and it looks like you could probably fine tune the crew skills in future too, though I'm not 100% sure of that.

There aren't currently any tutorials, tips or guides in-game and everything feels like they're subject to change. Figuring out the skills on the fly is doable, but Steam's community hub has already some starting guides to help you avoid the Trial and Error-method.

Game is very enjoyable, fun and has a lot of potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After over 900 hours played sense tech-alpha, I think I have a fair grasp of the game. My turn for one of these:

TL;DR If you like giant space ships and MOBAs, you need to be playing this yesterday.

Fractured Space is, at it's core, a simpler MOBA game. However, many of the more well-used MOBA bits and bobs have been thrown out, and for the better. There are no shops to comb though, builds to learn, creeps to farm and keep track of for pushing, or ultimate abilities that completely change the power level of things once level X has been reached. You have everything at the start of the game, as it should be.

It's just you, your team, your ships, and a few stations to battle over. You may think that would make things simple, but you would be wrong.

Instead, the complexity is moved to the ships. Each ship has a set of abilities, with loadout options you can get to alter those abilities slightly(WIP), armor facings to manage, and ways to complement your allies.

This is what makes Fractured Space great. You don't get stuck having to do tons of learning just so you can have a good time with the game, you just have to take a few minutes to understand what everything on the map is for, what your ship does, and you will be set. That is not to say that there is not a deep, deep dive into things to be had if you want to get into more competitive side, but you don't have to spend hours combing through guides to at least be alright. Low skill floor, very high skill ceiling.

If you want to spend some cash, you have plenty of options. Tons of skins at various price levels, some premium ships that look fantastic, and boosters that you can apply WHENEVER YOU WANT! None of that “Well, you had a booster running for X games and they were all ♥♥♥♥, suck to be you!” If you had a baller game, you drop those boosters on that game, and can save any others for the next time you carry the team on your broad, meaty shoulders.

All in all, Fractured Space is the game I did not know I wanted, and am honestly happy to be existing at the same time as.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although this is (or will be) a free to play game, their development priorities seem far from where they should be.  They seem to be focused on the art design of the game in their dev blogs, when gameplay and mechanics are far from finalized. This is especially frustrating for current supporters of the game, when we are expecting progress towards a more complete game and they continue to release more skins (microtransactions) to seemingly milk out their already limited player base. When this is a game regarded as a paid early access alpha and you prioritize microtransactions, you aren't selling an early access game but instead a final product, and this game is far from finalized. With these thoughts in mind here's the pros and cons:

Pros:
-excellent graphics and effects
Cons:
-Poor game balance (Certain ships are entirely outclassed by other ships)
-Endless Microtransactions
-Toxic and limited playerbase (The game's only major clan, He3, is present in most games and do not provide the healthiest of conversations to say the least)
-Ban-happy Developers*

* I mention this, because of a few cases that I know of where bans have been issued for seemingly no reason or justification. Especially when this is supposedly in early access development, I find it extremely disturbing that a company would focus on banning players to protect it's player base of at best 200 people from petty arguments during a match.

In conclusion, this game would be wildly successful if the developers get their priorities straight. But as of now it doesn't look like this will happen and I suggest staying away from this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update (06/06/2016): The Devs have returned the old crew members to players who had them, yet the case system still remains & the party size is still pitiful.

As of the patch on 5/13/2016:

DO NOT PLAY THIS TRAVESTY OF A GAME: THE DEVS HAVE DESTROYED IT.
They would rather prioritize ways to take your $$, than actually contribute to better gameplay.

This game, which was once an amazing space combat moba in development, has been reduced to a horrible shell of itself in an effort to squeeze as much money as possible out of what was an already dwindling player base. The latest patch looked as if it would breath new life into the game, but instead it has just turned Fractured Space into a massive grind for in-game currencies and experience, which can only be averted by spending real world $$ on cases which offer small amounts of them randomly. Unlocking crew members for the ships (giving % bonuses) is exceedingly difficult, as you earn the ability to use them them randomly from case spins, THEN HAVE TO PAY DNA (type of exp) TO UNLOCK THEM FOR YOUR SHIP! On top of that the balance for the game is terrible, they have rendered half of the ships impotent and the other half invincible, and instead of trying to fix balance issues they just LOCK ships from being used again (e.g. the Paragon).

I have just spent 3 hours playing the 6 game requisite for all the free cases you are entitled to each 24 hour period AND THEY GIVE NOTHING. From those 3 cases, I earned as much exp and credits equal to playing a 7th game: for 3 hours of effort, I recieved ~30 minutes of reward. What an absolute farce.

The fact that this patch was a giant cash grab and didnt even add the ability to make a full 5 man party is probably the most insulting aspect of it. I still can't party with my friends to slog through this inane grind for cases, instead I have to deal with the near endless stream of infantile players who don't understand that this game is about capturing objectives and not running around looking for easy kills & leaving you to die when things get rough. No players seem to take the time to do the training or read ship details to understand their roles.

This was an awesome game that originally avoided the pay to win that kills off so many games, but now it has succumb to it, and I will never be returning.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good game even at the Alpha stage.

It is a MOBA-style game: 5v5 teams, class-based charaacters (or rather, ships), lanes BUT no creeps, no towers and no jungle".

It uses a twitch/simulator style of control where you move your ship with WASD keys and aim your weapons (and abilities) with your mouse
date:
instead of clicking somewhere on the screen where you want the ship to go.

Instead of travelling with your teams creeps down a lane that is protected by turrets - there are two bases and several capture points in each of two lanes which give your side advantages (in the form of automatic upgrades for your ships) as well as access to the teams base (via capture of the two bases in a lane.

Rather than winning by destroying the enemy defenses and ultimately torching their "ancient" (like in DOTA...or any other fantasy MOBA) you actually have to CAPTURE the enemy base to win. Think of capture points in Team Fortress 2
recommended: where a superior number of the enemy will cause the capture point to slowly turn to your side and a superior number of defenders will halt that capture. The capture % does not go down
hoursPlayed: so once you've made some progress in capturing the enemy base
voteText:
that progress will not be lost...and the same applies to your base being captured as well.

That's the basic overview of the game "rules".

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game.

Tips for new players.
-avoid those damn sniping watchmans and gtfo when you are alone and colossus is coming straight to you.
-If you see a protector on your team, keep him safe. If it's an enemy, kill it first.
-when gamma 30sec mark goes on and your base is safe, then go to gamma and get ready for all out brawl.
-gamma is really important as it can flip the tide of battle. The one with gamma will have killed or crippled the opposing side's ships and will have time to capture 3~4 stations for leveling up.
-gamma point will at one time open a portal to the enemy base for the capturers so when you got a portal open in your base....get ready to defend at all cost.
-Don't warp when you are being fired upon. You will take insane amount of damage and get killed. Try to warp when you are out of the enemy's range or have some obstacles between you.

good luck and have fun :)

I really want to love this game but with the current state of matchmaking it's far from perfect. The quickest I've ever found a game is about 3 minutes. Usually the more common scenario is that you'll sit in line to play for 3 minutes and then someone leaves the queue and it causes you to start all over. 10 minutes to find a game seems more realistic. And if your 10th player can't be found the game will occasionally start at 4vs5 which is completely unfair.

The game itself has everything I wanted from Eve Online without any of the nonsense like griefing and grinding to get resources. There's 3 base ships they give you to start out and they're all great, I find myself going back and using them after unlocking more advanced ones. Sure there's definitely balance issues but it's still in early access.

Now, in my opinion I think the way the devs have focused so much on microtransactions, skins, and premium packages and not on things that are debilitating to the game such as the matchmaking and disconnects that will eventually ruin the game.

I sure hope that doesn't happen and that matchmaking will be more streamlined in the future. I'm giving this a negative review now because of the heavy focus on pay2play content while there are still terrible features like matchmaking.

Early Access Review

Not for the casual gamer. Fractured space has LONG (20-40 minute) battles. A mix of the old-stlye X-Wing & Wing commander space game physics - meaning it's not like an FPS at all. The strategy is simple: your team must control mines to get enhancements, and you need enhancements to overcome the enemy and take over their base. But the tactics are what is very different. A handful of battleships slugging it out around asteroids requires different skill than normal shooters where 'spray & pray' works. To top it off each ship and loadout changes gameplay, as does the loadout of your opponent.

The downside is.... 20-40 minute battles, and at times not enough players. Waiting 10 minutes for a match sucks. Getting started only to have 2 teammates drop out sucks more. The game has yet to reach the critical mass of players  - so stop reading and try it yourself!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fractured Space immediately caught my attention when I saw its superb graphics using Unreal Engine 4. The ships are beautifully designed works of art. The whole concept of taking space battles & adding them into the 5v5 MOBA genre is absolutely amazing & it works so well. There are always online battles going on with plenty of players to keep the fight going. The game's servers find matches very quickly & seem to work seemlessly & lag free. Our team was faced with higher level rival players a few times but the game quickly auto balanced the odds by giving our team quicker respawn times. I liked the leveling up system, hiring of crew & ship upgrades that are available but like World of Warplanes & other similar games of the like, expect to grind if you want the good stuff.

I would like to see more upgrade options for the ships. Another good idea would be to add ranked rooms or ladder matches for future tournament opportunities.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a sentence, yes, I do recommend this game to both people that enjoy space combat games and any MOBA fans.

But that's going to be my main point here, because I disagree with a lot of the other reviews here. If you're into pure space sims, of which there aren't that many of, then you might be a little surprised by Fractured Space.

Fractured Space, at its core, is a MOBA. It has more in common with LoL or DoTA than space combat sims. In fact, I'd hesitate to call this a space sim. I simply say that because, while yes, you do control huge starships with a variety of weapons and 'abilities', and yes the armour on each side of your starship is tracked, other than that the game doesn't really try to go into any deeper 'simulation'. Movement is entirely free, but it's not realistic in terms of space physics. Your health is tracked by a simple number.

In many ways you'll find traditional LoL/DoTA mechanics 'translated' so that they make sense on a sci fi starship theme. If you've played Beyond Earth, you'll probably understand that already.

I bought into the game not really sure what to expect, and I'm not a MOBA fan. I don't enjoy LoL or DoTA. At first I was disappointed at what appeared to be fairly shallow sim mechanics, but the deeper and more interesting parts of the game lie in teamwork and co-ordination, as well as pulling off a successful move or combo that sends your opponent up in flames.

TLDR; from my perspective, even though it's a bit disappointing for someone who was expecting an in-depth multiplayer starship sim game, it can still be incredibly fun as a space themed MOBA and will be a totally viable alternative in the MOBA market when it releases.

I would recommend, though, that unless you wish to directly support the developers, avoid 'buying' the game before it releases. Simply my opinion on F2P games that require purchase to access early-access. It's early, it's not finished and is a little content light at the moment.

Don't mind the alpha testing, the game is not only playable in this state, it is a perfected example of MOBA genre, where you only need skill and teamplay to win.
It could probably use more content (at least one more map would be really great), but given the pace at which the devs introduce patches and new features, I imagine new content will not make us wait for too long.
Getting high-tier ships may require some grinding, but this is well compensated by abundance of ships and new strategies to play.
Although the game has some glitches (matcmaking issues), it is very well coded and runs smoothly, with FPS and ping being in reasonable limits.
10/10

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

There's a lot of people talking ♥♥♥♥ on this game.

I'd like to disagree with them. So I will.

Okay, first off, I love this game. It's a moba without the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t grind for farm, with reasonably timed games decided by strength of tactics and skill. Unlike, say DotA, where cancer picks win the game (lookin at you Ogre Magi, Jakiro offlane. That ♥♥♥♥ is broken).

The graphics are top notch and the game runs butter smooth even on my 5 year old comp with max settings. Unreal Engine 4, I love you.

The audio of the game is beautiful. I'm not really an audiophile, so I can't talk about bitrates or samples or whatever. All I know is that when my Captain taunts the dude I just killed, it makes me happy. The WHUMP of an enemy exploding is musical. The sheer panic in my first game when hearing a missile lock coming my way. It's good, that's what I think.

The gameplay is... Okay, I wanna say 100% good, like the others, but there are a few niggles. Collision models are a bit off from ship models, so you'll find yourself bumping into things you think you wouldn't if you try to cut really close to objects. Especially the stations, those things have tons of little nooks and crannies to hide in.

The map is pretty decent, though it's a space game. There's space. It's space. not much to look at : / But it provides cover and tactical options like any moba. Plenty of opportunities to break line of site and jump away from a bad fight, or hide in ambush or even flanking to take an enemy by surprise that your buddies are already lighting up.

So far, I havne't found any issues with balance. There are definitely counters, and strong ones, that completely annihilate their counter. Reapers completely destroy Collosi. Brawlers Destroy INterceptors, etc. I haven't gotten to play all the ships, but I have plaeyd against all of them. FYI, stealth ships suck, the backstabbing pieces of ♥♥♥♥ XD And repair ships like the Protector are OP when paired with a Collosus, Gladiator or Leviathan. So long as you protect them, ironically.

And now, the part where people are taking Umbridge, the Monetization.

Yeah, it's there. No, it's not a big deal. Buy boosters if you want, they double your income. You get free drop-pods (Little goodie backs that give you stuff) every day. So far, the Crews are the only thing that come from those exclusively, but I got a decent crew right off the bat and there aren't very many crew to choose from and their bonuses vary only slightly. Think of them as runes and masteries from League, only less important; They buff you a bit in the early game, but they don't give you an edge that can't be overcome by skill. The premium ships are purely cosmetic (aside from unlocking them instantly, you get nothing special and, in my opinion, they're ugly and make you a big glowy target.) Other things, like the founder packs, grant you a limited number of goodies, but above all a stacking buff to EXP and Credits that counts for every person in the match. And that's the extent of the monetization.

The other half of this that gets mentioned is the GRIND. There is a small grind (think CoD4 or Bad Company 2), but if you're enjoying the game, you won't notice it. It's that small. You can unlock most of the early ships, one of every class, within 10-20 games. More kills/captures/supports means more credits/exp.

Which reminds me of my favorite aspect of this game: You get rewarded for supporting just like kills. That's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. Support points grant you exp and credits and count towards your MMR, so being a support main is viable. A good protector can tip the balance in a fight, easily. So, if you're having trouble winning and aren't getting a lot of kill, switch the a Protector and keep your buddies alive. Attach yourself to a Collosus and carry them to kills.

First and foremost, this is a game of tactics and positioning. If you aren't careful with where you move and when you jump, you'll get completely shut out by more experienced players. Even jumping while pointing the wrong direction can get you killed or waste precious minutes as your lumbering ship turns around. Oh yeah, Jumping preserves your Vector (direction and velocity). Think portals and you'll be fine (Speedy thing goes in, speedy thing comes out.).

SUMMARY:

It's a good game. For an Alpha, it's incredible well optimized and will run on a potato. Servers are great (Rarely top 120ms even on europe servers.) The only downside is the lack of players. Off-peak hours it can take more than 5 minutes to find a game. On-peak, it's more like 1-2 minutes, which is on par with almost every moba.

And, as with all moba's, remember to be friendly. So many new players get turned away because they get flamed by more experienced players. Teach them, help them and they'll learn and help this game stay strong.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: This is an EARLY ACCESS review. The points listed in this review may be subject to change. This review is intended to help you decide if you want to put some money down to get alpha/beta access to this game.

Gameplay OverviewThe goal in Fractured Space is to capture the enemy base while preventing the enemy team from capturing yours. To do that players choose from a selection of large capital ships (as I write this there are currently 6 types available, more are planned) with different weapons and abilities. The map is divided into several sectors containing star bases, mining stations, etc. for the players to capture. Captured mining bases generate resources for the team that can be used to upgrade your ship. Once a team has upgraded their ships, they can try and take over the enemy base.

How does the Combat feel?The 6 ship types currently in the game offer some nice variety in the way you engage your enemy. We have a Sniper" type ship with a limited firing arc that can charge up shots and do massive damage over large distances. The "Flagship" can take a lot of hits and pack quite a punch
date: but its guns have a very limited range. The "Hunter" is relatively fast (they still are capital ships and feel quite massive when steering) and can blink (short-range teleport) to get into or out of fights
recommended: but is quite squishy. The "Assassin" is even more squishy
hoursPlayed: but has the ability to cloak and lower the enemy defenses before unloading a salvo of missles into the unsuspecting target. With the "Disruptor" there is also a ship type that fits more into the classic "support" role with its ability to repair itself or friendly ships
voteText: and disable enemy ships weapons for a shot period.\n\nThe weapons range from (almost-)instant hit laser beams to slow moving projectiles
helpfulPercent: depending on your ship type. With the different weapon ranges
votesHelpful: firing arcs
votesTotal: and turret placement Fractured Space is as much about positioning and manouvering as it is about aiming. A ship with 4 turrets on the top side and 2 on the bottom side will try to get beneath the enemy
votesFunny: a "Sniper" will try to stay at a distance so the enemy can't return fire. Smaller ships can try and flank the "Sniper" so (because its firing arc is very limited) it can't fight back. You will see ships circling each other duking it out in close combat
commentsCount: as well as ships playing hide and seeks using the asteroids and star bases for cover. The latest iteraton of the sector maps encourage more "vertical" gameplay
column16: and planned changes to the sector jump mechanic could also promote more flanking.\n\nOne thing that can really hamper your enjoyment of the combat is low fps that has been reported by several players
column17: even some with higher end machines. The developers have stated that optimization is one of the priorities right now
column18: and that they are looking into other problems that might cause low framerates. You might also find that your weapons/abilities do not fire
column19: do fire but don't seem to do any damage
column20: hit some invisible wall instead of the target
column21:
etc.
The game is in early development.
There are lots of bugs.
You might get low fps.
You might even not be able to start the game at all because it keeps crashing.
The devs are making improvements and fixing bugs

Yes, i recommend this game.

I wouldn't have done it a year ago, in pre-(?) Alpha stage. Back then there wasn't a tutorial so you just have to live with playing games against the pros... that seriously didn't work out. now they added a tutorial which makes A LOT more sense. the graphics got a lot better, some more ships, ...

I've been playing Elite dangerous a lot the past year and i really felt at home with the community. when i gave fractured space another go i got the same feeling. a community that helps eachother out.

As for ingame explanations, it's imho incomplete ... there are some things that need an ingame explanation still (like passive shields, what the number of crew members does with the ship, ...)

The community is definetly a plus, but also a minus. the most people i've seen online till now are about 350. that's sad, thought there would be more people interested in capital ship combat (Capture the point). I got the game for free a year ago, if it keeps me entertained for 20 more hours i'll support the devs with one of those premium packages (don't really add anything beneficial, some skins, a premium ship i won't really use since i'm almost 100% medic in class based games,  an exp. + credit buff for you and your whole team, and a premium title. You can buy those packs in the steam store (forerunner, vanguard, ...)

If you are amazed by huge capital ships, 3D naval warfare and like class-based games... i'd say give it a go!

I have to say, this game is really cool. The detailed ships and unique design work really well together to create possibly one of the coolest sci-fy games out there.

But...

As of the posting of this review I must give warming, the game is only decently optimized, such high quality visuals does take it's toll. Since the alternate game mod test I have been unable to play because the game has become severely jumpy and laggy. I only move on my screen every 2-3 seconds, but i can tell that i am moving to others though. The UI also registers some friendly ships as hostile, with red outline and red icon on the minimap, but I can't use abilites on them, which is a relief. In short, amazing game, high possibility of breaking.

Galactica, Serenity, The Millennium falcon, Macross. What do these all have in common? They're science fiction ships that we love and adore. In Fractured space we get to have our own epic vessel and battle to the death.
World of Tanks meets (insert MOBA here) is the best way to sum up Fractured Space. It doesn't change the wheel as far as the genre model goes. However the combat and over all look of the game is very impressive.
With plenty of ships and good design in place. Fractured Space has plenty of potential.
However it is Early Access. There is bugs, there is no tutorial, Snipers are goddang OP. Issues are going to arise.
Perfection is a journey. Only time will tell if Fractured Space becomes the next best thing. So far its doing pretty darn good though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't be fooled by the mixed recent reviews. Seems like pretty much all the negative reviews recently are due to the fact that some people can't be bothered to read what they buy. They paid for alpha access before others and gain various benefits even now, but apparently they should get their money back now that it's open for all when this game was always supposed to be free to play. Which apparently was clearly stated on store page when they paid for it too.

The game seems pretty polished for early access, and mostly seems to be lacking in tech tree and perhaps different maps/game modes, but that's to be expected at this point. The game mode in this is mobaish two-lane push to win tug of war where you try capture recource zones in order to gain levels, and prevent enemy from leveling. In the middle of the map there is an shared objective called gamma which comes online for contest every few minutes and give general buff for the whole team to pretty much every stat and every subsequent buff gets stronger. The main objective, as usual, is the destruction of enemy home base.

I have only scratched the surface, but the game feel pretty tactical and the ships seem quite balanced and have some paper/rock/scissors mechanics to them. You have to keep an eye out for overall situation on both lanes and for gamma objective, and warp around the map as situation calls for it. It's a mighty feeling to warp in middle of a big fight at just the right time to turn around otherwise losing battle to your teams advantage and then take an important objective or even win the game afterwards as a result of your timely arrival on scene.

The grind" is gathering experience with different manufacturer ships and then unlocking ships how every you like. You may need to unlock some ship before the one you want if they are in a same development line. The ships aren't tiered so they should be all equal in overall strength. Although some ships require more exp and credits to get than others. Different ships mostly have different stats
recommended: accessories(skills) and playstyles so there is no hurry to open anything in regards of gaining more powerful ships
hoursPlayed: it's more of finding a ship to suit your playstyle and your team composition.\n\nOverall this game has been a very positive surprise. I barely installed this because of the mixed reviews(because I've come to expect that mixed/negative reviews on f2p usually mean p2w which isnt the case here at all) so I feel that I must recommend this to anyone who might be put off by the mixed reviews of reading impaired petty people too. The game is solid and free so give it a try. It may or may not be your cup of tea

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to give Fractured Space a cautious recommendation as it is still a very early alpha. It's a very playable alpha, granted, but there's still a lot of very basic features missing.

The good:
+Ships feel different and handle like capital ships of great size.
+Abilities and placement are important.
+Crew setup, upgrades and team comp feels important and has a lot of depth.
+Games are long, but always feel rewarding.
+Ships look great and the graphics are overall pretty good.

The bad:
-Some very basic things are missing like filtering for servers and the options to make a party.
-The UI presentation is confusing and is a little too minimal, there's a lot of information that's easy to miss.
-Expect ships and abilities to be over/under-powered. I personally had a lot of trouble with the Sniper ships, as of right now.
-Very few players, except during free weekends.
-You have to grind to unlock new abilities and ships, unless you buy in-game currency.
-The music is quite lackluster.

Bottom Line:
If you're itching to step onto the bridge and command your own ship into battle then Fractured Space will certainly scratch that spot, but bear in mind that it's still alpha and the game still needs more work.

October 2015 update:
The game just got a huge update which has vastly improved the crew mechanics and seems to have balanced out the different ships far more. Snipers seem to have been reworked, thank god. Furthermore, we have a new game mode that is shorter and more action packed, but it is possible to base rush which can lead to some games feeling cheesy. I would still make this a cautious recommendation, but with the knowledge that the game is improving.

November 2015 update:
Another big update just released and with it a much needed 2 part tutorial to help new players learn the basics of the game. You can now also freely choose between the two game modes. For the next update I would love to see more options for the ship abilities and more new crew to choose from, especially a Gunnery Technician that could increase your turret turn rate.

January 2016 update:
Matchmaking has been released and it's now possible to party up, before searching for a match, however it's only possible to party up with one friend so far. The tech tree has been reworked and so has the tutorial. The 30 % faster respawn time granted to teams with a disconnected player is not enough and should include a minor stat buff. Finally, for the next update I would really like to see more crew and more loadout options for the existing ships.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

4/20/15 Alpha Review:

Had a ton of fun playing over free weekend and the game has incredibly solid core gameplay. Obviously the gamestate lacks divertity in gameplay and strategy but I plan on closely watching the development. Additional maps and further loadout customization will result in a dynamic game with great replayability.

My only complaint is games tend to take a long time, often 30+ minutes for a single round, much of this is moving into position rather than actually engaging. This might be due to my preference for playing heavy defense ships to tank for the team. Coordionation is crucial to success, and having even one teammate drop out leads to a huge difference in team strength especially in do or die moments.

As of now the game lacks proper matchmaking and established teamplay, but from what I read thats down the pipeline.

Final recommedation - give it a try, play a few rounds. It was really fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Updated on Jan. 11th, 2016]
The day one alpha version of this game was practically good enough to warrant a $10 purchase. It's got solid mechanics, different kinds of ships with different playstyles and strengths, progression trees for unlocking new ships/guns/equipment (however some are still being built so many ships currently only have one loadout). It does a decent job at filling that void we all wanted EVE Online to fill: piloting massive ships in firey combat against one another without just point-and-click, RTS-like combat. Although while the ships are huge in reality, the controls and the absence of tons of smaller ships does kinda make the scale feel a bit smaller.

But yeah, this tends to be the game I keep coming back to when I get bored with Elite Dangerous or my other space games. There are around 20+ ships, so even though I've played the crap out of this and I have everything unlocked, I still always have fun by just playing a different ship every game or so. Small base of constant players, but definitely enough to always get into a game without sitting in warm up for too long. Noobs welcome too! The community is pretty supportive and most people will answer every one of your questions in game. ABSOLUTELY worth $10 to everyone (including non-space-fanatics). I'd say it's probably worth more like $20 to an absolute space fanboy like me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alot of people has given this game negative reviews lately.
They are angry because their progress got wiped, despite being told about it several months in advance, despite knowing that this is an early access game.
And they are angry because they now have to work in order to unlock things. Buhu.

And now, onwards to the game itself!

The game is a MOBA, and I do not like DOTA 2, nor LoL. But this game is nothing like those two.

Progress system, I love it!
As of now, there are 3 companies, each with their own selection of ships.
In order to unlock other ships in a company, all you have to do, is to play a ship from that company.
No need to play a specific ship in order to unlock the next one, just need to play the specific company. Love it!

Crews can be obtained, which will boost the ships stats - As of now, this implementation is unfinished! Let me repeat that, because alot of the negative reviews lately, is because of how this crew system is implemented. It is not done. The Developers are listening to the community, and has already made some changes, and has said that they will be making more changes.

I apparently suck at doing reviews, and excel at stepping on people toes, so -

Capital ships, in space. 'nuff said, get in the game!

Early Access Review

As it stands, this game is cool, if perhaps a little rough around the edges.  The gameplay is surprisingly fast paced considering the game's style, and there were no major glitches or problems I noticed while playing.

That being said, it seems like there was a major connection issue for me.  I'm not sure if it was on my end or serverside, but I would get booted from games frequently.  Also, there was a tendency for the losing team to end up with fewer players toward the end of the match.  Whether this was due to player drops or player boots is unknown.

Overall, I would say this game is worth ten bucks, especially if some of the wrinkles are smoothed out.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAfter playing a few hours, I found myself complaining about bogus deaths and lack of team support. Those are actually good things, considering it's still in early access stages. It's almost like playing a complete game already. The lack of content and instruction isn't as noticable after you jump in and play for a bit. The general pacing of matches seems quite on par with what you'd expect with 'capital ship' combat. Ships are very slow to turn, and can take a bit of a beating before going down, depending on which class you play. Depending on whether battles get much larger in the future, the potential for even more mayhem is welcome. For now, it's restricted to smaller, more tactical matches. I'm liking the classes as well, they seem fairly balanced at this point, at least until upgrades come out. I'm really hoping this one avoids the 'pay 2 win' stigma that haunts so many other class based team games out there now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recieved this game for free back on the first free weekend well before it went F2P.

As this game gets updated quite frequently my previous review was out of date so i figured i would update it so here goes.

Whilst i do recommend this game mainly due to the fact its F2P i would warn you like many F2P games it is now incredibly grindy. In the time it took for me to unlock a tier 2 relativly cheap ship the brawler i could have pre tech tree update unlocked at least 2-3 ships. The grind is now incredibly long. Although the Xp grind isnt too bad the credit grind sucks (Ships must be unlocked with manufacturer specific XP and then bought with general currency). For me the grind has been a major turn off for the game. Also as part of the tech tree update my previous ships were all reset so i have to grind ships now.

Pros:
Gameplay is really solid. Capital ships feel slow and heavy like they should more games really should do this style of gameplay. Ships also feel unique like MOBA heroes each with specific roles and playstyles.
Graphics the graphics are pretty good the ships for the most part look really good with each of the 3 manufacturers(Think countries in War thunder or WOT) having a specific style of ship design e.g. The Zarek have got a boxy design continued through there ships. However the environment could do with work aside from the bases which are massivly improved now.
Variety. Theres a lot of variety in ships theres over 20 ships in game now i think. Each one plays differently and has unique abilites. Some include the basiliks black hole. Or the Leviathans fusion  beam. Whilst other abilites carry over to other ships e.g. Missiles and strike craft are seen on a lot of ships. Also whilst there are several cloaking ships (Assasins e.g. Infiltrator, Ghost, Basilisk) Each one plays differently with the basilisk being a support ship in comparison to the offensive styles of the others.

Cons:
Grind. Its pretty ridiculous imo. XP grind comes first and is over pretty quick. Then you need the credits and say youre grinding your first ship you will often find yourself with all the XP and half of the credits meaning youre now grinding a 2nd ship to afford the next which means by the time you have the XP for the 2nd youre massivly behind in creds. Some ships are also outrageously exspensive. Also anyone wanting to play a cloaker now has to wait an age and the easiest to get is the basilisk and the Widow one of which sucks as its too easy to counter and the other is good but doesnt really play much like an assasin. Also the grind forces you into playing certain ships repeatedly e.g. When i was grinding for the brawler i only had the pioneer starting USR ship which i hated to begin with. Now i am grinding for the basilisk and i would be forced into playing the sentinel which is a ship i hate due to my hatred of autoaim guns. Also its just boring for me. Fortunatly i have the revenant a limited time ship given away a while ago so i at least have got a good ship to play in that tree but repeatedly playing it still bores me
Ship designs. Imo the ships vary from being really awesome e.g. Colossus to being fairly lackluster the new superlifter looks like a box. As does the gladiator. Or the interceptor which looks spookily similar to a reaper or paladin. I get manufacturer ships should look similar but a bit more variety is nice.

Of note a lot of people complain about the paragon (Carrier) being removed i dont really mind the ship was a major irritation when it was around had too much health imo and didnt really acomplish all that much. But my opinion on it is if the devs felt it shouldnt be in the game thats there decision and i agree with them it wasnt working and wasnt functioning as a carrier should but i look forward to a future one.

Again to sum up its a cautious recommend if you like battlestar galactica or various other sci-fi stuff then this is pretty awesome but if you have a job and dont want another then the grind might be too much for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As this is preliminary review for Early Access, I will try to sum up pros and cons with brief commentary.

Overall for Early Access: 85/100 (updated after 09-APR-2015 Patch and following hot-fixes)

Visuals:
+ Perfect graphics, good work on details
+ Rotating camera
+ Enhanced visuals,
+ More tactical looking map
+ Possibility to rotate camera without aim change (press Alt to do so)
- Sometimes it is hard to see behind the ship
- Hard fights might be laggy
- Engine sometimes forces to lower the resolution for smooth run (temporary)

Gameplay
+ Huge amount of servers
+ Good selection of ships, two new added
+ Dynamic engine
+ Crew has stats and influence for combat, can be recruited and combined at will (temporary limited)
+ Simple, yet ellegant menu
+ Team change added (press F4 and after opposite player does the same, it will occur)
+ Teamplay matters more after last update
+ Well balanced ships
o Transforming community (temporary, a lot of new players after free weekend)
o Abilities work only on English layout (temporary)
o Controls are better, but still fail sometimes (very rare)
- Team matchmaking missing (temporary)
- Sometimes laggy servers
- Few minor glitches

Soundtrack
+ Background menu music
+ Sounds of guns and explosions

Other content
+ Reputations with manufacturers
+ Research and unlocking ships
+ In-game shop (content limited, temporary)
o Two-stage unlocking - first experience gained, then purchasing for credits

Fractured Space does have a promise to be a good MOBA game, mainly through its innovative idea - space battles. Content in menu is so far very limited, but game is capable of being played and provides excellent audiovisual experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

***Early access review***
I was excited when I found this game. I've always loved space shooters, but I got tired of saving the galaxy in a starfighter. Capital ship combat is where my heart is.
The game at this point consists of 5v5 rounds that generally last from 10-25 minutes. There is a decent variety of ships to choose, but they must be unlocked with experience. Despite other reviews, I don't think it takes overly long to unlock the various ships (I'm up to 10 or so at 30hrs). Subjectively, I'm unlocking ships on here faster than I'm unlocking tanks of WoT. I'm having fun unlocking ships, and it doesn't feel like a grind to me. There are multiple classes of ships to support multiple playstyles, and the dev's seem good about balancing and re-balancing during this stage. Despite the fact that the ships don't maneuver as fast as in starfighter type games, the game still has a speedy pace. The direction of battle can shift wildly at a moments notice. You can be on the verge of losing one moment, then snatch victory from the jaws of death with great teamwork.

I love it. Sure, there are problems, but this game is still in testing. I like the direction that the game devs are taking it, and they are constantly working on it.

Pros:
Beautiful graphics.
Fun 5v5 combat.
Variety of ships.
Game is well optimized for online play. I rarely experience lag issues at server end.

Cons: **remember, this is early access**
Small playerbase means you generally wait 3 minutes for a match
Matchmaker needs work.
Currently no provision to join a match in progress. This sucks because sometimes you get an idle/AFK/disconnected player in the match that needs to be replaced.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warning: 64bit OS requirement or you can't play it (yet).

That said, Fractured Space is a very solid 5 v 5 small scale space combat and it accomplishes this very well, with a comfortable variety of ships, upgrades, and controls that make it easy to get into.

The only downside this game has is it's strange server system that only allows one match of 10 people into a server at any given time and 2 servers per timezone.  For the moment this isn't much of a bother because the population is terribly low, but hopefully with more time and success they will improve on this so it's easier to go from match to match without seeing the same players over and over.

I highly recommend this game to gaming clans, for the low price of $20 USD per 5 pack it is very much worth it if you have other players in mind to bring with you into the game.  For the base price of $10 USD for one, it isn't worth it yet until the population problems are smoothed out and gameplay is more regular.  That said, when things pick up, this will certainly be a game worth $15 USD per purchase.

I have had a short but sweet experience with it and sincerely hope to see it succeed, as I would like to continue playing it even when my clanmates are offline.
