reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first I didn't think this game was gonna be that great... Common, a Moba space game where you fly around in Captial Ships? Doesn't sound that appealing to a non-fan of capital ship fighting. All I can usually think about is sitting their firing at another ship for 10mins, untill someones shields finally go down, and then you got 5 more mins of Hull to tear through.

Well, let me say, this is nothing like that at all. This game gave me one of the best outcomes of an early access game I've seen in awhile. The mechanics are all there, with plenty of movement room for expanding.

The game is alot more fast passed then one would initially think. And on top of it, each ship class is incredibly unique in their play style.

Although there is no player progression yet, it is definitely setup to be very successful.
The tech trees are alot like World of tanks. However the gameplay is alot like a Moba, but without the boring minion farming. Your team levels up together, and no single person is ever overpowered or ahead in dmg or health. And on top of that, the currect ships are very balanced. None seem to be overpowered.

From the looks of it, in the near future, your crew will sort of act like passive stats added to your ships, and then with the tech tree you can switch out your skills for ones that more suit your play style.

Extremely excited to see what is to come with this game.

Date of rating: 01/02/2015
9/10 - Gameplay
10/10 - Audio/Voice Overs
9/10 - Mechanics
4/10 - Progression (at the moment the tech tree looks sound, however it is not yet fully implemented due to earlyaccess)

Overall Rating - 8/10  ...The current gameplay is very fun, and does not get old. Even though there is no progression yet, the game itself is very addicting. I am consistently finding myself starting up the game!

In a years time, this could definatly be as big as World of tanks, or League of Legends!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For those who won't read relatively long reviews. It's a good game, it's fun, it has a good community and good Development team. It may have some issues but they should be fixed sorta soonish.

I am long overdue for writing a review to this game clearly as indicated by my hours played. I'm not very good a objective reviews but I'm going to try my hardest to do so.

So Fractured Space is a free to play game about big old capital ships duking it out in a 5v5 situation. It has amazing visual and audio effects for all ships, though I will admit some are more fitting than others. The gameplay is extremely compelling and involved and you really have to do your research if you want to get good at it. This game is not for the faint of heart or the ones that easily give up. It's a very hard game at the start and can be very punishing. Each ship you can play feels unique and perfectly distinguishable both visually and in a gameplay sense. The game also has a great community behind it and i've made many good friends playing it.

The major negatives I can think of are all mostly excused by the fact that this game is still in development but that doesn't mean it shouldn't affect your decision. The game has a lot of minor glitches and bugs, most of them don't make the game unplayable but for the nitpickers it can be a little irritating. The game is also really not optimized so those with potatoes for computer might not have a lot of luck with this game. I hear a lot of complaining about the servers from others but I have fine responsiveness and performance from them despite having an average of 200 ping. The game is also currently not in an amazing state of balance in terms of the ships themselves but Edgecase (the makers of the game) is not currently invested in ship balance because they are focused on putting all the systems in place before they are 100% functional. Balance is still on going but it isn't a priority for them.

On the side of more good things I can say that this game is genuinely a bundle of fun. It rewards the skillful and encourages teamwork. It's very tactical and really drives you to think about every action you take. The map is separated in to five sectors that you have to use a jump drive to access. The game is also filled with a variety of brilliantly designed and voiced crew members that provide bonuses to your ship. Something else to note is that the developers are very responsive to player feedback on the forums. They read almost everything even though you might not think it.

I apologize if this review feels a little jumpy and all over the place, i'm not good at structured writing. The big thing I want you to take away from this review is that the game is a ton of fun and while it may have some problems, they will most likely be fixed in the near future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fractured Space is an arena shooting space combat game... think World of Tanks in space.

Though in Early Access, there is a good, stable and fun gameplay system already inplace which pits two teams of 5 players, or ships against one another for control of three space sectors before jumping in to destroy the enemies main base of operations.

The game currently consists of 6 ships ranging from the fast moving Frigate through specialist ships to the large and dominating Flagship.

There will be more ships added in the future as well as a credit and XP system where you choose the faction you want purchase a ship from and as you earn XP and credits you may advance down the line or upgrade the ship.

This game has tons of potential and I highly recommend this game for all space combat lovers, especially if you love flying and shooting larger ships compared to your every day fighter.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThere exists a cycle, known to many, that often occurs when getting a new game. Buy game - play for ~10 hours - go back to playing CS:GO, TF2 or whatever your particular gaming staples are. For myself, however,  Fractured Space  breaks this cycle, and has becoming an instant favourite. It just doesnt get boring. Even though in its current Alpha state there is only one map and gametype, no two games are ever the same. Maybe you'll be fighting a pitched battle for a space station and get overrun, your ship erupting in a shower of flame and flying debris, or possibly a friendly will jump in at the last second and repair your crippled hull, thrusting you back into the melee. There is also plenty of ships to suit all playstyles - go big, dumb and loud with the Brawler or Flagship and wreak havoc, or take the cloak and dagger approach with the Infiltrator or Assassin. Whatever your playstyle, for fans of the MOBA genre or multiplayer in general,  Fractured Space  is not one to be missed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm one of the early players of this game and I could say that before someone could have a full grasp of the game, they need to play it more than 10 hours and understand every aspect in order for them to see how good this game is. This is not the type of moba for the faint heart. It requires complete teamwork and all ships are balanced.

There are some players who thought that they needed to unlock higher tier ships in order to become stronger and this is wrong. Higher tier ships are balanced vs tier-1 ships. The only difference is that higher tier ships requires higher knowledge of the game in order for you to fully unlock the ship's potential.

I have played with one player in a queue who cursed one of the final tier ships saying that it was too weak when in fact that ship can actually deal a great amount of damage from a distance. He was using the ship in close combat.

For new players who wanted to learn more about the ships and its unique abilities, there are community guides available in the forums to assist you. This game is still fairly new and the player community helped the devs a lot in order to make this game better every single update, which has been happening till now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of people are reviewing this game off of bad performance, rating a game because your computer can't handle it isnt fair.

It's still very early access and has some faults but has a huge amount of potential, nothing is forcing you to buy the game now other than to support the developers and you can help eliminate bugs and help bring light of this game to others.

The developers plan on making this game free-to-play so just wait if you wish, watch youtube videos of it if you have anymore interesting in buying it and READ the system requirements to make sure your computer can run the game.

The game uses the UNREAL 4 engine, everything is beautiful, even on all low the only difference really is shadows and some texture differences.

Controls are easy to use, Q and E for left and right, W and S for forward and backward, spacebar and ctrl for down and up.

There is a quite a bit of stuff all over your hud, but whenever I feel overwhelmed I just press F2 and the hud turns off, this game has a fancy laser sight that shows where shots are going to go that I use to aim my weapons and I remember my 1-5 keys for weapons and abilities.

If you love spaceships, love epic medium sized to capital ship sized combat this game is great and should only get greater.

Some of the only faults i've experienced are the lack of players on game lobbys, but this is just because the game just kicked off a month ago on steam, and it's early access which is a hit or miss nowadays on steam, and sometimes im not entirely sure why, the game just crashes, thankfully I can easily rejoin the match and continue the game but I wish I knew what was causing it (Maybe too many key commands because its only ever happened when im fighting atleast 2 people and i'm freaking out?)

The progression system seems to be like War Thunder and World of Tanks, you have a corporation(Faction) with its own tier ships which have it's own mods(Different weapon types and equipment) and ships that can be purchased.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has always been well polished and good, and I'm writing this review mostly to offer a moderate perspective on the problems.
People have been complaining about the crew unlocks, well honestly, the crew don't matter at all, so it's a moot point to me.
It is a slog (not too bad but still a slog) to get any new ships, especially if you're not fond of a manufacturer's base ship, but once you've unlocked the one you want it's not really a big deal. The starter ships are also pretty decent and I still use them on occasion.
Not being able to party up with all your friends kinda sucks, but I understand the reasoning of not wanting 5 man slamdowns of 5 people paired up who can communicate and such.

The game is fun in and of itself, I wish the ships felt bigger though. They move too fast and just seem like oversized toys to me, which is no fault of the models, they're gorgeous, it just seems like toys fighting each other sometimes. More small stuff for scale would be nice I suppose (more visible machineguns for point defense, more fighters, etc).

But really, when you're in a full team battle to the end for gamma or a home base and all the ships are close together slogging it out, it's a damn fun game and I highly recommend it, especially now that it's free.

I've only encountered one or two squeakers and most of the time everyone is nice and happy to help, so the community, while a bit small at the moment (although I've never had the egregious match finding time problems others report, perhaps it's because I'm in the US East? Who knows), is a good one.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is wonderful for an early access game. after about 4 hours of playing it I have noticed some small problems with balancing. For one the sniper ship needs a a little more range to it but otherwise seems very balanced. The starting flagship feels wrong, it needs more armor bt otherwise nicely done. From what else I've seen everything else is decently balanced just needs a couple tune ups. The tech tree is structured fine. The loadout section is interesting but the armament upgrades need to offer more. Like a rocket upgrade should change your volley to 10 instead of 8. Diversity is key in this game. If you have diversity in ship types your set and should have no problem winning against a less diverse team. Maybe add a more defined pre-game ship selection and show how many of each ship is on the field so that all roles can be filled. Everything else looks good and it's a wonderful game for alpha. GET THIS GAME.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An interesting, albeit content-starved game where two teams of capital ships slug it out in an attempt to capture the enemies base. Sadly lacking currently in the player population department as well but I haven't had too much difficulty finding a game.

Gameplay is fairly slow and methodical, but in my opinion manages to capture this certain 'visceral' feel with impressive visuals and sound design. Ships feel very hefty and powerful.

In it's current state (as of the time of writing), there are 6 ships (with a small amount of customisation) and one map/game mode (the aforementioned standard MOBA type game mode). It's a small start, but the things that are already there are promising.

I've heard of others complaining about poor optimisation and sudden framerate drops but I have yet to experience anything of the sort. It may be worth looking into though if you are on a lower end system.

For the $10 asking price, I'm happy with the product, especially considering the prospect of more maps, game modes and features in the future. This is the foundation of a game (in early alpha), and unlike some other early access titles I've played it's a very solid one. I'm excited to see where this goes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What is Fractured Space
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tSnMwJpOfRE


I got Fractured Space during the free weekend and I have to say, I've enjoyed nearly every minute of it so far, and to me for a game that is in the Alpha stage of development, that is far beyond my expectations.

The good:All of the ships look awesome and most of them have a very unique feel to them. Handling a small fast ship is very different from piloting one of the huge lumbering beasts that are also available.
Games are fun and engaging, especially when the special Gas facility opens up every few minutes and the usual fight over the 2 flanking sectors makes way for a single big battle for control of this precious resource.

The bad:With important information scattered over different places, the game takes some time to get into.
It can take quite a while before you'll be able to unlock the more specialized ships. The more specialized the ship, the more expensive it is to unlock.


From what I understand, since the free weekend, Fractured Space has seen a huge increase in its player population, resulting in new games being filled up quite rapidly leading to few games which are not 5Vs5.

Since it is still in Alpha, the game does take a bit of effort to get into but once on the main screen you will find an overview of what goes on during a match as well the goal along with the controls for the game.

With currently 12 different ships to pick from, there is something for just about anyone. Whether you want to dish it out up close and personal, attack from afar or lend support in different ways to your allies, there is a ship for you. Even individual ships can be tweaked in small ways, by changing their load-out. This is also where you will find a more detailed description on each of your ship's systems, including their effective range (this was perhaps the biggest issue I had when starting my first match and had little idea of when my target was within weapons range).


tl;dr
Great 5Vs5 moba where you take control of capital spaceships that takes some time to get into.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Boiled down to its most basic, Fractured Space (FS) is a team game, where team composition, communication and tactics can really come into play.

:Game-play:

This is very much a team game, and really doesn't support lone wolves all to well. The objective is to capture the enemy home base. The map is split into five areas, each with their own bits for capping.

The first two are the team's home bases. These areas contain the home station (the win condition) and two mini-stations (I generally call these nodes to keep things clear).
The next two are the two main arena areas, Alpha and Beta. Each area contains two warp points (these are needed to be capped to jump into the enemy base) and three nodes, as well as asteroid based cover.

Lastly we have Gamma which is bang in the middle. It is warpable to from any area, but you can only jump to A/B warp points from there. There is only one structure here, the gas station, which is only cappable periodically. Capping it gives your fleet a huge boost to damage and recharge rates for about 2 minutes (or till death if they die before that time expires). Each time the station becomes available for capping, the bonus will be greater than the last.

Games are always 5v5. You enter the match with a pre-selected ship, however during warm-up or first entry, you can choose a different ship to better suit you team build. But once your ship is selected, that's it until the match is over.

:Mechanics:
Capping: Points are capped by entering their bubble of influence. Capping speed is determined by the amount of ship levels in the bubble versus the amount of opponent ship levels in the bubble (I'll explain levels next). I’m not sure at what multiples you have to be at to cap an area with enemy still in it, but you have to have significantly more levels than they do.

Levels and nodes: Maximum ship level is team wide, and is increased by capping nodes. Nodes generate points when capped, and when the points hit the right amount, your team levels up. You however do not automatically level up. Instead, you have to fly back to a capped warp station or home base. Levels increase damage, health and recharge rates, with each level growing exponentially (e.g. the jump between 5 and 6 will be far greater than 1 and 2).

Combat: The main feature of the game. Every ship has different ranges on it's guns, as well as some having optimal range before damage drop off. Many ships also rely on their facings for their weapons fire arcs. Whilst some ships can fight at any angle, some have to face certain ways to bring guns to bear.
Another aspect that is little often discussed is armour. Each ship has 6 different armour facings, being front, back, port, starboard, top, and finally bottom. As a facing gets repeatedly hit, the armour will take damage. Once it has taken enough, it will drop (represented by the facing burning) and any damage taken against that facing will increase.
All ships have abilities. This is what defines their tactics and play style with some ships able to generate different kinds of shielding, others have more support weapons, and mother with support drones or fighters/bombers. Each ship has three “class abilities” assigned on the 1, 2, & 3 keys, and “general abilities” on 4, 5, & 6. Your general abilities are Point defence(4), used for intercpeting missiles and hostile drone/attack craft, Warp to(5) for moving between locations, and Warp Home (6) which is a longer warp, but will always warp you to home base no matter the location (unless already home)

:Ships:
There are a multitude of ships to play with, each with their own unlocks to change out their equipment. Each ship will fit roughly into one of three categories, Defence, Support and Assault. All of which is pretty self explanatory. Composition of your team can be really important. Focused too much in one aspect can leave you woefully exposed, with certain ships being better on taking on different classes of ships. For example, the Assassin (A “Tier 3” unlock) is fantastic for taking out lighter ships and support ships, but will struggle against heavies and dedicated combat craft.

You start off with access to three different ships from the three different manufacturers (There is a fourth, but nothing has been released for them so far).

Flagship: One of the two heavies so far released. This is a defensive class ship, mainly due to its ability to tank huge amounts of damage. Despite having a short boost ability, it is very slow and with guns that are really focused on close range, it can feel really cumbersome.

Hunter: This is your first assault ship. It's nimble, it's guns are some what close range, and it has to be careful with it's facing. It can do micro-jumps to get it in range, can fire missiles for longer range and can detect nearby hidden ships. It has to keep a forward facing towards it's target or suffer huge DPS drop as it won't be able to bring it's other guns to bare.

Corvette: Your first support ship, and arguably the most useful. It's very light, meaning it's fast, but can't take to much damage. It is a dedicated healer however. It's main gun will have it's shots home towards your locked on enemy, allowing you to focus on your team mates. It's main features are it's repair beam and shield, allowing it to heal and block damage respectively.

My Summary:

I really do enjoy this game, however, as it's still in alpha, there will be a fair few changes in the future, as well as few bugs. I got it on the free steam weekend, but I would recommend it, even you just get it at it's cheapest price. I look forward to seeing what new features will be made for it. Bugs are currently few and far between, but can be very annoying, even match ruining if you come across one, but they do seem to be fixed pretty sharply. If you wished to hold out until it's more developed, I wouldn't blame you, but as it currently stands, the combat is nice and varied, with plenty of different ship types to keep matches interesting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK so I was looking for something new the other day...........AND I know this game is early access, I am going to give my experinces so far:
For some reason the game would not launch and required a reboot( this is after playing initially and coming back after a while)reboot worked.I have played as many matches as I have had lose connection, seems to be 50/50 for me getting through a full match. server lists are buggy and show no players, some ships change controls after warping (hunter) and the ballance is off and people are definitely taking advantage of this right now, also I take heavy (from 60 to 20ish) FPS hits in certain situation (4690k and gtx760 both OCed and running current drivers) but I can still play through the spikes ( not game breaking).

Having said all that I do recommend this game with all its bugs for 10 bucks when it works it is great fun!! there are great moments when the stars align and you get in with a good group.... these few matches make it more than worth the struggle/frustration. the grafix are nice and I personally love the sound. It is a neet idea, and I think lends itself well to a group strategy and I think the depth of strategy will not be apparent at first. I love how the maps? are laid out and there are multiple ways to conquer the enemy, the only downside is a group that dosnt comm will probly not win against a group that talks, (nothing new). There is some good concepts here and I hope the Devs will follow through and polish this title... it is very close to being very good with some tweeking. I do have one concern however and that is that the game shows the framework for potentially going free to play......

if you've played sins of solar empire, nexus, homeworld and loved the theme of those games, your gonna admire this, the only difference is that your the one fully controlling those awesome capital ships against other players with capitals ships as well.
there are 3 types of ships.

- defense fleet ships which are the most awesome and are used to hold the front lines and are the biggest.

being that the game is still in Alpha means that u will encounter bugs, but nothing major, the game is perfectly playable and enjoyable.

overall I see a bright future for fractured space, it's a great and fresh idea, and no it's totally different from drenaughts or whatever the other similarly themed game is called. these are capital ships with thousands of crew memebers a floating town in space. but the other looks kinda arcady, this one is more like a simulator and need alot of tactics and coordinations between team members.
I should also add that their constantly adding and improving stuff, and their match making wait time is very short given the fact that it's still in alpha.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game in many ways is a pretty standard arena push game. There are control points on the map and you push from your base to the other base to win.

However, the full 3d space enviroment givinf you 6DoF is a really nice touch. Not to mention the nice space sci-fi theme. The ships feel good when they move. They dont always feel fast, sometimes they feel really slugish. In this case, thats a very good thing. These are supposed to be large battle ships. They feel heavy and armored, and armed to the teeth.

I was able to pick this game up and within just one or two matches I knew what was going on and what I was doing. Within that same number of matches, I went from getting my butt handed to me, to winning with really decent K/D ratio. Honestly though I just chock that up to feeling really comfortable with the assassin ship, which is a hit and run cloaker.

I think this game has a lot of potential. I really like the ability to pick the crew for your ship, which so far is cosmetic, but pleasent as all the crew so far are fully voiced so they have battle chatter.

All in all, the game looks good, it feels good, and it is a lot of fun. The dev is on the right path, and I am very excited to see what comes next.

It looks like they intend to add many more ships, and the ability to customise your ships equipment and abilities to some degree.

I would definitely recommend this game to others. Just keep in mind, it is in Early Access at the time of this review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

== Review Based on 13/12/2014 version of the game ==
Fractured Space is just excellent as a concept, I love the idea of cap ships just slugging away at one another.
The game feels incomplete but the core game mechanics are a Lot of fun in its current state; well worth the really low price.
Here’s the good;
•	Core game mechanics are in place and they are fun. The combat is immensely satisfying, intense, kills feel good and deaths don’t feel cheap.
•	The game has a strange, methodically slow pace to it. You are encouraged to think laterally and plan manoeuvres – some may complain about this but I think it is a very good thing.
•	The verity of ships and different roles they play all feel significant, no one ship ‘feels’ gimped, all have their strengths and weaknesses.
•	The devs are proven and have a clear plan for development of this title.
There are a couple of caveats at the moment though;
•	The game does not currently support pre-made teams; this will be a problem if you want to play on the same team as your friends.
•	You will feel the FPS drop on occasion – this is fairly normal for a game in development, optimisation will come with time.
•	While the core game mechanics are (mostly) done and really quite fun, a lot of the meta – inter-match gameplay and higher level mechanics are currently missing, this makes the game feel incomplete and may be a deal-breaker for many. To those people I’d highly recommend waiting and seeing what happens as development progresses.
•	Those who don’t like Dota style 5v5 3-lane combat may be put off as the game appears to draw some influence from the likes of Smite.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great game so far, but slightly wanting in customization and replayability. You'll find yourself enjoying the simple space combat, timing your shields between cover and the anticipation of that desperately needed missle barage. It's quite a spectacular game to take in: beautiful graphics, the perfect sounds, you can even see the detail of individual turrets and thrusters working as you command your vessel. The issues however, that despite the enjoyable gameplay, its repetitive with little motivation to play frequently.

To the dev: so far my experience has been a pleasant one, however more often than not, if one side starts to lose everyone jumps ship and leaves just a few players to fend for themselves. If there were credits to spend on customization of say crew or appearance, or maybe even equipment (keep it balanced please) then players might actually stick around. Or perhaps when one side starts to win there could be some sort of balancing feature like faster respawns for the losing team. As it is when one team starts to dominate the field, they're the winners. Also I hope to see more done with the crew slot aspect of the ship other than voices. Perhaps a slow combat regen, faster jumps, faster captures. It would be nice if your tactical leader have more purpose besides base cap as well, capturing an enemy ship perhaps using boarding pods ? Also it would be nice to gear up your ship how you like but they have a 1-2 locked abilities/ weapons + stats including what already exists, but perhaps add in targeting systems that allow for faster turret turning and accuracy increases. Finnally some sort of engine overdrive that isnt the ftl, would greatly increase the gameplay speed and skill involved, not saying make it a fighter jet, but some sort of depletable bar.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: This is a review for the Alpha stages of this game.

I started playing back in January, 2016 during a FTP weekend and haven't looked back. I simply love this game, despite some of the issues it's had with Matchmaking, crashes, etc. It's in Alpha, cost me nothing, and I still want to play this game daily! It really is a mix of World of Tanks and League of Legends (insert MOBA here). The ships are amazing, love the variety and the Devs truly try to make everything balanced (can't be easy). I'm looking forward to new maps, new ships, and new modes in the future as this game develops.

Pros:
- Fun to play
- Great looking modeling of ships
- Dev's truly care
- Balanced for an Alpha
- Love that it requires some strategy to win and be successful (most of the time), not just fast twitch reflexes

Cons:
- Need some new maps (fly through wreckage graveyard would be cool, IMHO)
- Greater server stability (it's getting better)

Wishlist:
- Being able to see your stats; IE: W/L ratio for individual ships you fly/own, previous match history, stuff like that.
- Did I mention new maps? :)
- MORE people playing! This is a great game! And it's Free! Play it already! heh

Thank you,
mmmcoffee

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After a break i had - in wich a wipe took place - i returned to Fractured Space and saw again why i like this game.

It is basically a MOBA with capital (space) ships from the third pespective. You got your to expected weapons, utilities and drones to fight against other ships. There are currently three factions with a (yet sparse, some would say) tech tree with different ships to research. The main types also apply in Fractured Space: Offense, Defence and Support with according abilities. (May call them Damage Dealer, Tank and Healer). And even with the currently little pool of ships there are some interesting ways to combine your forces. Also you can form a crew, as you choose five crewmembers out of a bunch with different specifications and thus granting you some bonuses for the ship you can match with your playstyle (sadly there are quite few crewmembers at the time)

What i like about FS is the graphic and the design. The three factions have all interesting shipdesigns and i simply adore the modular construction of these giant spaceships. Also the sound is very pleasing. Ignore the fact of soundless space - the lasers ingame are awesome.

Of course you must keep in mind that Fractured Space is a Early Access game and so in state of developement.
There is only one map and gamemode aviable right now and you only can invite just one friend to play together.

But i hope there is more to come. Fractured Space has potential and i hope its gonna play it out right and draw the attention of all who like MOBAs, space and/or capital space ships.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I saw this in my library and decided to give it a go. I only played two games, but even still, I was able to do something as a starter nooby with nothing. I tried support in my first game and was healing up people in fights and throwing little drones at enemies. We won that one. In the second, I tried an attack ship and got 6 kills (as level 1 vs lvls 6-13). In that sense, it's pretty balanced, I'd say (compared to other games where you join as a new player and get decimated and can do nothing).

When I first got on, there were only two servers with players. One had 10/10, the other had 1/10. I was a little discouraged, but I joined the open server anyways and played a game. Afterwards, there were like 6 servers with players and it started growing, which caught me by surprise. I think more people should play this game :P


I, for one, plan on playing this more. (Few more details down below)




As some others have said, it's a team game. I had no idea what I was doing but figured out how to work with others, at least. When I was a little support ship getting hammered by a huge enemy ship, a bigger allied ship came in between us and soaked up the damage. I healed it up and we won against 2 others. In the second game I played, it looked like the whole enemy team didn't care about their team composition and played whatever they wanted. That costed them the win. Our team had a mix of attackers, supports, and a heavy. Theirs? I believe most of them were attack ships and there was maybe 1 heavy.

They say this when you get in the game, but because it's Alpha, there is no playable tutorial yet. However, they have a little video for you to watch that explains the controls and whatnot. That was enough to get me going at a decent pace. The rest, you learn as you go, I suppose.

Product received for free

Early Access Review

The pacing of this game allows some fantastic coordination between teammates (teammate quality varries same as any moba game which is why I recomend having a buddy).  I find that it strikes a fantastic ballance between long term planning and split-second decisions though many who are used to FPS game pacing might find it slow.  Ships are extremely diverse and there is one for nearly any playstyle and skill level.

The tech tree in this game does NOT mean that a higher tier ship is better, it means that the ship is arguably harder to play.

ECG has shown recently how willing they are to respond to player feedback.  I've only ever raised one complaint directly to them and they fixed it in 2 days.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game itself is very smooth and nice, but it is VERY hard to get into (unless, of course, you DO watch the turotial video! It's there for a reason) - there is no ingame help so far and noone's going to hold your hand.

The mechanics are a bit unusual for a MOBA-style game (capture points instead of destroying them), but after a couple of matches it becomes quite clear.
The customization is there, but so far it seems like 'if you bought the upgraded gun you're ahead' (snipers, I mean you!), and is not available for all ship classes.
The ships... They are vastly different, as they should be. Can't really talk about balance these days, I've only got ten hours into it, but looks like ship diversity compensates for it rather well.

All in all, I'm giving it my biased score of 8/10 (why biased? I'm totally ignoring the learning curve here, you know).
The graphics are gorgeous, the framerate is stable and the matchs rarely last longer than 20-25 minutes.
The downside? Point capture speed gradually increases over time, so the matches are usually decided by a couple of sneak-skirmishes and a final rush. And the fact that you cannot reverse the capture effect on your base (those assassins, ugh...)

TL;DR 8/10 if you can spare 10 minutes to watch a video tutorial, and 0/10 if you can't be bothered.

Overall a very mediocre game. Graphics are decent, sounds boring, simplistic gameplay, painful control scheme.

Gameplay is overly simplistic with far less options than typical fps or moba style games. This is primarily left-click or right-click on a target to shoot and like 1 or 2 very uninspired special attacks. Capturing stations is simply a matter of flying near them as they are all completely undefended. The level up system is also rather simplistic and yields little more than bonus hps and damage. Loadouts are also uninspired with weapon options having little more variety than for example average laser, laser that shoots fast and does lless damage and big laser that shoots slow and does extra damage; nothing that really affects your gameplay in an substantial way.

Ships are surprisingly weak for a game that bills itself on capital ship duels which tends to make the game feel very fps-ish. Many battles are over in just a few shots. Many movie/tv battle sequences last longer and they are paying like $1M a minute for cgi. This might be ok for if it was a fighter sim but feels totally wrong in a capital ship context. Also, the respawn timers are far too long making for too much idling. Ship balance is also very poor for an early access game that has been out this long. The support type ships seem generally unplayed and unuseful.

Immersion is very poor due to virtually no consistency in the styling of the various ships. They all look decent but there is little stylistic consistancy like they were just ripped at random from coolspaceships.com or someting. Many of the battles take place at ranges where its difficult to even make out the appearance of the ships so you feel like you are mostly just attacking hitboxes.

Currently, in Early Access there is only 1 map and once again it is a very uninspired symetrical 2-lane map.

The only victory condition is to cap your opponents home base. Unfortunately, they made a very dubious design decision in that there is no way to decap your home base meaning that rushing the enemy base is a pretty easy win especially with the short cap time needed and really long respawn timers. Its not unusual to see matches end after simply 1 or 2 clashes not much room for strategy or comebacks.

Hopefully the game gets better - there is certainly some potential here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love the idea of a space combat shooter, so Fractured Space is definitely my kinda of thing.  Unfortunately, the thing I've always loved most about space games is full freedom of movement.  And that's where Fractured Space falls short for me.  The game is actually played as if you are on a flat plane, just like a first-person-shooter game when you're underwater.  You can float upwards or downwards, but your orientation never actually changes.  This means no banking around an asteroid, no complex evasion to shake targetting, and no fun feeling (for me) of being in space.  This game feels far more like a game of submarines than a game of giant space warships.

I can't really recommend Fractured Space, and I doubt the reason for my objection will change as they exit Early Access.  I want something more like Freespace + multiplayer, and I don't think that's a direction the devs plan to go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I personally love this game. It is a MOBA at heart, but if you don't like traditional MOBAs don't be discouraged. This game is straighforward but manages to be interesting all the same. It is also VERY well balanced, and I will explain what I mean below.

SKILL BASED COMBAT
This game is all about skill. The ships all have tradeoffs, so that no ship is truly better than another. Let's take the overseer, a sniper ship with a long range laser gun. It is weak at short range. You would think it would be OP since, space is space and there is a lot of open areas. Wrong. There are many ways to close or combat it, just like any other ship. Bombers, stealth ships, fast agile ships and blink drives all give sniper ships trouble.

Ship Classes
I like to divide the ships into the game into 4 roles:
Combat Cruisers
-Medium range ships that take decent beatings and dish out decent damage at , very balanced (ex. Reaper or Venturer)
Dreadnoughts
-Big slow and heavily armed for short ranged (ex. Colossus or Leviathan)
Destroyers
-Fast small ships with varying firepower and interesting abilities[I include stealth ships] (ex. Ghost or Raider)
Support Ships
-All shapes and sizes, these odd ships fill specialty roles that can make a real difference when supporting the damage classes above [snipers are support, not carry] (ex Protector or the Paragon)

So some people complain about how some ships are good and some suck. This is not the case, it's just they do not have any skills besides brawling and/or straight yolo rushes. Fights are quite nuanced between skilled players. Each ship has it's own playstyle. Most players use a few meta" ships
date: which are quite strong and have simple gameplay. These are usually combat cruisers or dreadnoughts. I love using specialty ships and ships with hidden potential to counter cruisers
recommended: which make up the bulk of players. I also end up being called a hacking ♥♥♥♥♥♥ a lot. Name of the game: Skill and playstyle> Quote "Meta" ships\n\n10/10 would be called ♥♥♥♥♥♥ again"

I've always liked the idea of space games, but never found one I truly enjoyed.
But THIS... this is the MOBA I've always wanted. Highly enjoyable. Great graphics. Teamwork oriented space-ship warfare.
Be a massive capital ship and lead the attack, or boost your teammates with tactical special abilities. Stealth it, ambush, capture resource stations, fight over territory and upgrade your ship before moving in on the enemy base.
I'm excited that it's still in Alpha, it means there's more to come. More ships. More upgrades. More game-modes?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I may not be as experienced as mainy of the other players and reviewers who have been involved with Fractured Space but I can say that with everything I have experienced within the 10+ games I have played, I Love This Game! It's everything I could ask to have in a space game where you control one of mainy big ships in a team of 5 and fight to control the battle against another team of 5 big ships, there is a fair amount of strategy involved since there are Relays (Alpha 1 and 2 on one side & Beta 1 and 2 on the other) to jump too and 3 mines inbetween that net your team Resources (exp?) if you control them. Gamma station in the middle which periodically goes live and needs to be captured to gain your team a buff and then the 2 main bases where either team spawns with 5 turret generators to be destroyed and then the base to be captured to win.

This explination is far from the best but it's the best I can do in terms of making it simple, each ship has its own style of abilities and role to play in combat ranging from different offensive roles, defencive roles and support roles. The fact that it's free to play is also very inviting, I also feel that the game is far from pay 2 win because within my experience all the ships I have come across (3 starter ships and 7 other ships from different tiers) are all fairly balanced just rely on the player executing their role properly to do well in the game.

So anyways thank you very much for taking the time to read this some what amatuer review and I would definitely recommend this game if you love Big Battle Ships in Space! - 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Synopsis:
5v5 moba style space game with a large variety of ships. Each ship is designed to fill a role and overall its a well balanced game. Ships are unlocked with both a faction experience system and currency both are earned by playing the game (you may bypass the currency part with real cash not the faction experience). Game has a crew system to slightly alter the base stats of your ships but is very down played and crew take TIME to unlock.

Payment system: free to play real life money can be used for
RED PAINT (most important)
bypass currency in game (not faction experience)
slightly reduce grind
unlock crew slightly faster
premium ships (useless)

Pros
graphics are to die for (THE RED PAINT IS BEAUTIFUL)
ships well balanced (trust me the noob ships are OP)
lots of ship variety
player to player balancing generally effective
mostly polite community (except those freaks yelling at me the black widow is useless)
frequently updated with new content (mostly ships current player-base prevents new modes maps)

cons
not all ships get RED PAINT (RED RED RED RED)
lacks global chat system or in game friend system (steam friend system is integrated into game)
lack of map variety (map does change slightly each game but not much)
needs more players for game to grow (american east coast primetime takes 1-2 min to find a game never more than 5)

personal opinion:
good game worth the time more players would be nice but most importantly RED PAINT I NEED MORE RED PAINT

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a truly beautiful game. The level of detail each ship has is stunning. It's a joy seeing your turrents pivot and track your pointer. Your orientation is important, different ships have different fields of fire, some favor broadside action, others at the fore, others have smart guns that fire inderectly, and so on. It's a joy to see each turret open up depending where you are aiming.

No ship feels more powerful than the other, nor is one loadout better than the next, they just give you more options and choices, and the chance to really personalize some ships and find your own style.

In terms of gameplay, the 10 player matches are very intense, but newbie friendly. You can have veterans and newbies in the same team and not feel like you're babysitting anyone or the other way arround. The controls and mechanics are very intuitive, making the game easy to master. That doesn't make it boring though! The magic is in the slugging matches between crafts, and that never gets old.
It's very close to a perfect information game, you almost always know what the enemy is doing, and he knows what you're doing too. That means that strategy is key here, knowing when to split your team, or stay together takes a while to sink in, but seeing an impromptu party of strangers work together as a well oiled machine is worth it.

The company is very active and constantly adding stuff, with a new ship appearing in an almost monthly basis. This is a very solid and underappreciated game, and it's pretty unique in what it has to offer. It's less of a moba in space, and more of chess in space. Less about using complex abilities and gear and more about anticipating your enemy and cooperating with your ally. Worth your money and your time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is a lot of fun. As opposed to most space fighter games where you are a single fighter zipping around and shooting everything in sight, this game actually takes planning. Since you are a colossal ship, each move is important to the success of your team. You must plan with your teammates or risk being overtaken. Deciding on which side to capture is all important for when you make that all important push the their base. The different classes are different enough that there isn't just one superior class that all others lose to. Some a devastating alone, others are better in small packs and still others are best served with a support ship behind them. It's all up to you as the player and I look forward to this game's final release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a nutshell this game follows similiar rules to the likes of World of Tanks, Star Conflict and Warthunder etc.  The main difference being that its set in space with 6 degrees of freedom and you fly bloody huge capital ships!
Unlike the previously mentioned games Fractured Space has done a great job of making each ship unique with totally different weapons and special abilities making every new ship unlocked a new experience and as of now there is no tier" system whereas a tier 1 ship will get totally outclassed by a tier 10 ship etc.  This means that if you like one of the early ships then you are not forced to stop using it when you unlock other ships which i think is a great idea!
Ontop of this there is no forcing you to play a ship you dont like to unlock the next ship as all experince gained goes to the faction as a whole so in my eyes another big plus to the game.
The current content in the game is pretty small but they add new ships about every month or two and there is enough people playing it to never struggle to find a game and the latency so far during games is fantastic for me personally.
I have always been a fan of huge spacships and the idea of the slow moving monsters firing devestating broadsides at each other from 50km away and if you want that then its here!  If you want smaller
date: nimble craft then they are also here.  If you want snipers then you have them and if you want sneaky cloaky ships then its all here.\nThe game is great and is improving constantly and plays just fine on my pretty low end laptop on low to medium graphics and still looks great!\nIf you are a fan of small team based combat games such as WoT and Warthunder and also a fan of huge spaceships then look no further!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Reviewed as of 22 December 2015. Obviously the game is subject to change, bear that in mind for any review.]

Wonderful game. Ton of fun, active developer support, Lobbies fill up quickly regardless of region VERY easy to get a match going pretty much any time of day. It may take a few minutes to get started, but that's even true of player-count juggernauts like Call of Duty.

Fractured Space has interesting and fairly balanced gameplay. Every ship is relevant in some way, but choosing the right ship for the task always matters. Ping is almost irrelevant in matches - I've experienced no difference in gameplay between 40 and 350 ping. It's in early alpha, so there are a few problems that are typical of that sort of thing, but they're mostly addressed quickly and effectively.

There's one final progression wipe coming on the 21st of January, so playing before then might suck a bit if you don't want the exclusive skins they give as a reward for high-levels prior to the wipe. But the game itself is a lot of fun regardless, and definitely worth your time and the rather minor $10 investment it takes to get it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As an early access game, this has a lot of excuses for it's shortcomings. But given how well the product is presented as is, I am confident that the devs will fix most of if not all of my complaints. The main problem is the utter lack of explanation, whether it be a proper control tutorial, or how to accomplish in-game objectives. All you get is an image showing the key layout.

After some trial and error, I began to pick up on the nuances of each ship, and how they all contribute to a battle. The basic controls, once explained, are easy to use, with some fancy manuvering possible once you get the hang of it. Objectives at the moment are of the stand near to capture" variety
date: with little else to do besides shoot people
recommended: but the shooting itself is fairly complex with the number of unique abilities available to each ship.\n\nSlight gameplay inbalances and bugginess

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS and PROBABLY ALPHA!... NOTE THAT ABOUT THIS REVIEW!!

This game need ALOT of fixing and adding if its going to be worth anything.

However.. I will give an easy setup of good and bad parts of this so far.

Positive:

- Good space mechanics: It feels like you are flying a massive ship in space. Which is good cause its a space combat sim.

- Ships and critical points: There are ship classes that are somewhat ballanced. Some unfair (looking at the cloak and short range 1 hit kill switch one) , but it all makes it better when you can damage parts of ships and take even MOAR damage!

- Combat: Combat is slow, yet fast. Its like I have said.. It feeeeels like a space game that you see in Homeworld and typical space games/sci fi games. Cannons takes time to turn and same does the ships. Its like Star Conflict done more realistic.

NEGATIVE PARTS!!!

- Cloak and short range weapons: Probably the most broken ship in the game. Dont remember the name of the ship (assault I think), BUT YOU KNOW WHAT YOU ARE!! It is stupid. Compare to the Sniper class, this ship is broken and either needs a huge nerf or be terminated.

- The game outside graphics and game mechanics: Apparently from what I see, its going to be a MMO PVP MOBA ish game. It also has a cheap version of Star Conflict with the lobby. From what I see, there will be only online gaming with this game and no PVE.

- Gamemodes: Capture the enemy headquarters... oooooooooh thats boring... that is the only gamemode at this point. OOOOOOH THAT IS BORING!





There is really not much to say about this game, cause there is almost nothing in this.

Its not a bad game, just feel the DEVS are holding it back. ALOT. They could have added Deathmatch, team deathmatch or anything else to make it more fun, or even have more variants that are not so straight out of the class system book of any mmo / RPG game".
Owell. I suggest not buying the game yet. Maybe later? Only time will tell.

Gonna give it a thumbs up cause... the devs to see that they can do it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Whelp, they added rng to the game. Crew members give flat bonuses to your ship. Previously you could just buy the crewmembers you liked with normal ingame currency. Now you have to draft them from 'drop pods', which give you a random crewmember of varying rarity and power. Or sometimes no crewmember at all, instead pitifully small credit bonuses or DNA.

..what's DNA? Well! In order to use a crewmember after you drafted them, you still have to use DNA to actually unlock them. How do you get DNA? Why, only through openeing yet more drop pods, of course!

And how do you get droppods? Well, they come in 3 rarities. Each one exceedingly more costly in ingame currency. Or you could just spend a hundred bucks and buy 110 drop pods. Which won't even get you all the crewmembers. Bargain, right?

Early Access Review

Just completed my first game of Fractured Space as of this review.
I've never really liked MOBAs, which FS kind of is, but man was that fun.

*Slow, tactical gameplay that can turn into a very fast-paced space shootout in a matter of seconds
*Different types of ships have distinctively different playstyles, which is always a good thing
*Runs well on good-but-not-amazing hardware and apparently on lower end machines as well
*Gorgeous graphically, but not too much eyecandy to blind your view
*Clearly indicated support-role ships

Definitely going to play more of this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is based on my first impressions...
First of all, this game looks great. I'm fortunate enough to have a fairly meaty PC for it, and the ships look like the awesome, kilometre-long juggernauts of space death that they are. The weapon effects are nice, too, and give a nice impression of the amount of laser/missile/energy stuff the ships fling at each other, and the resultant damage.
Gameplay-wise, it's fairly straightforward: float around in big starships, unload weapons-based punishment on each other, and capture control points around the map, with the aim of capturing the enemy's home base (while they do the same to you). I was understandably not very good in my very first game, but it's fun enough to make me want to keep playing and get virtual medals, promotions, crew and ship upgrades as I strive to become un-useless. However, I like to think that I and my 6000+ crew members all died noble deaths. Again. And again. Like in Edge Of Tomorrow, but without the learning process.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I got Fractured Space a long time ago in a sale, because it looked cool. I played now and then about 10 games for 2 months. No grand choice of ships, just Protector, Hunter, Colossus, Venturer and maybe 5 other ships. Also the bases weren't painted or detailed.

I expected all of this from an Early Access game in it's alpha.

What you saw 4 to 5 months ago raised your expectations for this game and then I started playing again a month ago:

There are now very detailed bases in each sector with 3 or 4 different asteroid maps to battle in, the ships are absolutley gorgeous (except the ghost which reminds me of southparks a*** probe) and the effects are beautiful.
The Shiptree (or Character tree) now counts 26+ ships from 3 different manufacturers with unique looks and weapon systems.

I myself favor the Titan Defense Systems [TDS] because their ships feature an often sleek and well shaped exterior with awesome beamweapons and Smartguns [they're locking on to the enemy in a limited angle and do not make that much damage]. The TDS tree also offers some of the most potent healers [e.g. Protector, Paladin].

As far as I can tell most ships are pretty balanced, some are more or less annoying depending on which ship you fly.
All ships are accessible via playing the game and for most of them you need like 10 games.
BUT the 3 starter ships are completly sufficient and count to the [IMO] better ships.
You can customize the stats of your ship to a certain degree with specialized crewmembers [damage resistance, multiplier etc. pp. in the range from 4-10%]

Everything gameplay relevant is FREE TO PLAY [yes you can buy ingame currency and with it ships, but hey where's the fun with that; also there aren't any ships that are completly over the top good so you have no real advantage].
The ingame market sells only cosmetics and xp- and creditbooster [the latter you can aquire by lootcrates (so called droppods) which you get for playing at least 2 games at one day].

The general goal of the game is gathering as many resources through occupied mines in 2 sectors as possible, engaging in epic space battles at the main mining station in the middle of the map and ultimately capping the enemy base while destroying every enemy ship on the way [or vice versa :) ].

So I can only recommend this game to all people who like capitalspaceships, explosions, strategy and to a certain degree MOBA's.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have 4.8 (and counting) hours on this game. I advise you to consider this review not too seriously due to my lack of game-play time in it.

Introduction:
I found this game on a 'Steam Free Weekend' and I downloaded for a bit because I had seen TheMightyJingles play it and was heavily interested in it for the most part. After playing it that weekend, I had a bit of fun, a few frustration moments, and overall a good time. But after that weekend, I wasn't convinced enough to buy it, so I simply forgot about the game until recently it went into a 'Free-to-play' state, which I really liked, and I gave it another try and found myself loving it so far for these few games and hours.



Pros:
+ The game looks beautiful and amazing. I have it all maxed out on an Radeon R9 290 with an AMD FX-6300 and 16GB of RAM, and it looks simply gorgeous whenever I play it. (Considering all you'll see is explosions-mayhem-fest, this is a great sign of good optimization.)
+ It handles well with the network. I rarely see any lag spikes on my internet. Where I shoot, I score.
+ Simple to learn.
+ Space-ships are incredibly unique.
+ Roles are amazingly well diversified. (Support, Attacker, Tank, and so on.)
+ Easy controls to adapt to.
+ Excellent adaptation of a MOBA in space. It really works.
+ Game shines best if you're playing with five of your friends with TS on. It's a beauty to just steamroll everything with great communication and skill.
+ It doesn't seem P2W. I have seen those 'Premium' ships in action on the opposing team and on my team, and I have won against them. They aren't overpowered.

Cons:
- There's no Teamwork unless you push the team or play with friends and a microphone. (Get ready for ♥♥♥♥♥♥ matches if you're playing alone!)
- Grindy, as expected.
- The variety with maps is vague. I would love to see other types of maps.
- The variety in game-modes is even worse. I would love to see other types of game-modes.


Verdict:
Would I recommend this game? Definitely, but bring friends with you! -- 8/10


/// * Will update 'Cons' and 'Pros' as I go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game just want to get that out of the way now. Now for my full opinion on this game.

I joined during the free weekend of this game, however after playing 25 matches I have found out what I consider what the good bad and ugly of this game are. Lets start with the ugly.

Ugly - Its in early access.... ya .... as we all know this means the game can change or be cancelled at any time with very little warning so I myself after the stomping lands, and cube world fiasco have held off on purchasing early access games. That being said the developers seem extremley into this game and fingers crossed looks like they will for along time coming. More ugly now. The leaderboards in the current state are kinda really crap lol, they are working on it to drastically improve them but currently they are simply just bad. The in game honor is calculated very weirdly and makes no sense in its current state. You can organize the leaderboard by everything except kill death ratio which makes no sense to me since that is in my opinion one of the most important things to sort by.

Bad- Now for the bad this is the stuff that the game could fix with a little bit of work. To start weakpoints..... for the love of god especially when flying the sniper ship at weak points on every ship that makes the gunplay far more balanaced. It makes it more balanced due to the fact that now as a corvette or other small ship and you run into any type of ship that has damage you literally have no chance. If you added a weak spot the little ship now has a chance to out manuever the bigger ship and take it out by  hitting the weak point. Another that goes  hand in hand with weak points is ships being effected by damage. currently you can be shot wherever and  have nothing happen. However i should be able to aim for the engines of the opposing ship and take them out he should lose alot of mobility makeing him way slower atleast for a short time till his engines are fixed. giving players a chance to be extremley tactical in their battles with opponents. remember this isnt stuff necessary for the game but i believe it would add to the game greatly. Another thing for  future would be more maps and even larger scale battle so  instead of 5 on 5 maybe 10 on 10 just to make battles even more epic this is space lol.

Good- Finally to the good. As is this game has absorbed 15 hours of my time already and its only been like 4 days so ya im a little obssesed.  This is essentialy a space ship moba everyship is unique in damage health and abilities so it takes a little bit to find out what gamestyle you like and can do best in. The way to unlock ships is to use a ship belonging to one of the three factions. every game you play with gains xp to unlock new loadouts for ships in that faction and new ships themselves. Also every game you play you get credits after you unlock things with xp you then use the credits to actually purchase the upgrades or ships themselves. The gameplay itself is very very easy to learn and master. after about my 5th game I have not had a game were i didnt get 10 plus kills 3 or less deaths and 7 or so base captures. if you have a nack for shooters the game is fairly easy to learn and your personal skills matters alot more than in other shooters that put too much reflex gameplay into the way you play. The visuals in this game are also very beautiful and keep the blankness of space interesting. Matches unlike most other mobas take about 15-30 mins to play I just had my longest match every at 46min which is about the average length of a match in most other mobas so this game is much easier to play if you only get 30 min to play here and there.

Overall I would rate the game as follows

Overall 8/10
gameplay 9/10
graphics 8/10
audio 7/10
stats/leaderboards 5/10
I hope you enjoy this game as much as I do and I hope you support the developers to help encourage them to keep making and improving this game so i can come in and revise this post and rate the game a 10 out of 10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since it's an Alpha build it's hard to judge it because it could change at any moment. Anyway 2015-04-15 comments.

Final verdict: I got to play it during the free weekend and it was quite enjoyable. If I had to pay full price to play it I'd probably wait for the developers to add more game modes and to see what kind of premium options the developers plan to offer in the in-game shop.

There were 3 ships instantly available and 9 more can be accessed by playing the game and unlocking them. So far only skins for ships seems to be cash only with the potential for Premium ships and crew members to be added to the shop later. So far it's too early to say if these premium options will be pay-to-win.

Each of the ships has a primary and a secondary weapon as well as some other weapons.
Primary weapons are mainly lasers but they vary in damage, speed, effective shooting angles (for some the target needs to be right in from of your ship) and other aspects (some do more damage with each hit so you need to be very close to make sure that you hit all your shots, while some are slower and effective at maximum range).
Secondaries and other weapons can vary greatly,they can allow you to teleport to another location, activate extra shields, fire repairing lasers at you teammates, disable your target's systems, activate a movement speed boots and so on.
So far it seems the ships can be only slightly customized by choosing from some pre-set options (faster+less damage or slower+more damage and so on), but I guess that is needed for balancing reasons.

So far the only game mode is a 5v5 Domination. The gameplay is mainly team oriented, but if you are playing against a not very coordinated team a single player can still carry his team to victory, but generally a balanced team composition and a coordinated team effort (of defending points and attacking) is needed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic game, I've had tonnes of fun with my friends and it's a game where I don't get frustrated if I lose because I'm still having lots of fun. It's quite often with other games that I get angry quickly, so for this game to not bring that out is awesome.

Voice communication is essential to victory, I would recommend that ECG add in a voice chat system for each team, I've been making do with a TS server.

Another thing to note is that this is an extremely polished game for it's Alpha status, devs currently planning to launch Beta next year, but I'm yet to find any issues with the game other than a few crashes which got fixed from me verifying the integrity of the game cache through Steam.

Latest update has brought in a premium currency which so far just seems to be for skins and is NOT p2w which is awesome.

Keep up the good work ECG, I'm sure I will put many more hours into Fractured Space.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlright, It's about time a rewrite this review. It's been over a year now, and the game has grown a lot. Me still playing the game should give credit to my positive review of it, so instead  of talking about the game, I'll talk about some reviews I'm seeing from people with under 10 hours. From my own experience, this game is in no way pay to win. Sure, it takes time to unlock those high tier ships, but trust me, it's for your own benifit. I've never once felt the urge to pay for a ship in this game, so don't let those people make you think it's something it's not. It's more of a warframe like grind, though nowhere close to as grindy as that game. Everything is unlockable in game. The only other major problem right now(besides drones still being under developement) is the lack of playerbase. The matchmaking system is great, but there aren't enough people playing right now. I hope that it going free to play helps newcomers come in, and for those longtime players in there(you know who you are and what you say in chat) how about you try being a little nicer to people getting into the game? If you rage everytime someone makes a mistake, there eventually won't be any players left because of your bad attitude.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a fantastic game, but you must remember it is early access, and there are some issues like optimization, balancing, and a few bugs.

Now the game for me is rather laggy, at roughly 18 frames per second, 13 in large battles, but that's not the devs fault since my pc is a potato. However I've heard from friends with better gear that, while less prevelant, the frames drop/freeze on occasion.

Balancing, for the most part the ships are balanced, with a few notable acceptions, primarily the amount of teamwork required to run a gladiator effectively, the brawler, the paragon (actually locked by devs because it was so imbalanced), and the protector, who with the right crew only takes 25% of incoming damage, and out heals damage from 1-2 players simultaneously attacking.

Bug are bugs, it's alpha, they happen.

Now this game, dispite the issues, is amazing. The immersion is great, voice lines are great, all shops are well balanced, and a million more plusses. Some may say the grind is unbearable but that just isn't true. I was able to get a new ship within 4 games, and the more expensive ships require the grind because they are specialized. The grind is there to make sure you can actually play those late unlocks well.

Overall, this game is an 8.5 out of 10, higher once the lag issues are fixed (again, may just be my potato pc)

Also devs, please please please add in game comms!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is being made after the April update that rendered the game Free to Play and introduced the case system. i should also put a disclaimer saying that I bout into the Alpha and bought the highest priced package at the time, so there might be some bias.

First of, I would like to respond to some of the more vocal fans of the game that are complaining about the case system and claiming it's now a pay to win game. No. Some try to mislead you by saying that all but the starter crew are locked off and that this is causing a huge imbalance as people who pay unlock different crew. They are correct, you can only get the starter crew and do need to grind or pay to get other crew, but this does not affect game balance in any significant way. All crew are side-grades from each other, and while ships work better with crew that compliment their abilities, the affect is minimal and any specialized ship will lose something for it's upgrades. Any specialized ship can still be taken down by a starter crewed ship easily if that ship is used right.

Now that I got that out of the way, onto the review. Fractured Space is a unique game, taking elements from MOBAs and vehicle battle games like World of Warships, and for the sake of adding it in, Hero Shooter like Overwatch and Battleborn with the latter having a higher resemblance. The game relies heavily on team work, the correct ship composition and very heavily on how good yo are with your ship. The game can be a grind as you need EXP and DNA to earn ships and crew, but the starter ships give you everything you need for a fair and balanced team that can hold of most teams. Ships can be earned with EXP, which you get by playing games in ships of the same tech tree, and crew are acquired as random drops that you get in crates that also require DNA to craft. While the crew system is abhorrent, it doesn't affect the game that much and is the only major downside and is not as bad as others will have you think.

For an Alpha game, Fractured space shows a lot of promise and already lives up a lot of praise it gets. The gameplay is solid, although the UI needs some tweaks before release, and it looks amazing with the Unreal Engine. If you're into it, you could easily lose weeks to this game, and it hasn't even come out yet! Of the games flaws, other than the crate system, many of them are not the games fault. There still appear to be a massive amount of new players that don't know much about the game mechanics and the tutorial is still in need of touching up so that player will also learn how to synergize with their team mates. The two game modes are fun, although I have not played any Frontline and am basing that opinion on what I have seen, and it is always fun to ram your colossus into a disabled enemy Ghost. Overall, I recommend you get this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not a big MOBA player, this is the first one I've played for more than an few hours - most of them have bored me.
So far I'm enjoying my time with Fractured Space. I like the setting, the graphics are excellent - it's a fun blast.
Would I recommend you try this game? Absolutely - and I paid for it.  Now it's free it's a no-brainer.

I do suggest you watch some guides, your enjoyment level will skyrocket the more you understand how to be an effective team player. There is also lone-wolf play but it's much better when your team work successfully smashes the enemy.

Why have I written this review now? I spotted the negative reviews - I don't agree with some of the complaints.
Give it a go and decide for yourself!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm absoloutely loving this game, I'm a World of Warhips veteran & consider this the next level in massive ship combat - Adding space into the mix really gives you some extra tactile options, there is a whole new axis to movement afterall!

The spaceships and graphics look amazing, I've seen no space game come close to looking this good - I'm running a GTX 980ti and im getting over 140FPS in Ultra.

I have 6.7 hours gameplay on record thus far and this is without a doubt my favourite game in my steam library now, I've purchased the Vanguard DLC for £15 while it was 50% off - Got some great looking skins and a premium ship which is not more powerful than most of the standard ships, but it has cloaking capabilities.

THIS GAME IS NOT A PAY TO WIN - Whoever says it is just cannot be ♥♥♥♥♥ to play and unlock ships in the tech tree, this is exactly like WoWs or WoT - You need to play atleast 6 games per ship to unlock all of it's capabilities and move onto the next one, it helps if you have some multipliers to boost XP gains like being a Vanguard but that's no different from Wargaming offering a premium option (which i use alot).
Putting money into this game does not give you any advantage over the players around you. - I Promise. (I die alot, even in premium ships).

The controlls are super fluid, the ships move around exactly as you would expect and you can see all the Retro rocket thrusters pushing your ship around through space as you turn, straffe & bank.
Some ships have abilities like, boost which really has a lovely effect on it when the main engine cranks up and blasts you through space.
the game kind of feels like a moba in terms of how the map behaves, you have a Left"

Awesome gameplay, team work is vital! Ship selection matters to aid your teams loadout. Each ship has it's own 'special abilities' loads of ships to select, ranking is easy enough. I enjoy playing this game, it's fun. Great visiuals, epic battles (reminds me of battlestar galacticar)

community is small at the moment, i usually play a player I've seen before every game, this isn't a bad thing there are always games going, get involved buy this game, you will not regret it.

Cons - just being picky, game is in alpha and there aren't many modes/maps. But this will become a very popular game and more who invest are giving the devs the ability to put more monies into the game.

10/10

Early Access Review

Still very early Alpha so the game is a bit rudimentary and buggy still.

BUT the concept is really entertaining. Its very fun to play! Thinking about later stages of development I must say this is a game with a lot of potential. If you love space battles and intense fighting give it a try. Its worth it.

Only a few basic ship types available at the moment. But all have very differeent roles and give you very different possibilities to play against the enemy ships. You have cloaked Assassins, Disruptor ships that can heal your allies and disable the weapons of enemys. There are Sniper Ships, Huge Flagships etc.

Highy recommended and fun game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why all the non-helpful votes?

Even if this game has many flaws, it is going in the right way. Try it yourself. Its great.
This game is a capitol ship combat simulator. instead of flying in your cramped small starfighter, how about a massive capitol ship with thousands of (expendable) crew-members? Add on beutiful visuals and brilliant effects, and you have got this game. This game is an intense 3rd person ship combat sim, every moment, you will be making a dicision that could save thousands (or kill thousands). Game balance is near perfect. Every ship has its unique purpose, and stats, with a counterplay for every single one. So no OP sniper you cant seem to get.You can also deploy starfighters and watch as a massive space-dogfight unfold infront of you (until of course, your point defence gets into range and shreds the opposing fighters). With bullets and missiles flying everywhere along with beutiful explosions, this game is a tru masterpiece, in both aspects of gameplay, and visuals.
EDIT(6/14/15): Many balance fixes, and new ship. This game is getting better and better!
